English.title: Cardano Blockchain Ecosystem Budget: Amaru Node Development 2025
English.abstract:
[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) is an open-source project implementing a new fully interoperable block-producing node for Cardano. It aims to improve the network's overall accessibility and robustness without compromising its safety and security.

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) provides another perspective and solution for stake pool operators and developers alike, prioritizing a modular approach, a seamless user experience, and low hardware requirements. Additionally, the project is implemented mainly in Rust, which is well-equipped for high assurance to attract new contributors to the core maintenance of the ecosystem.
English.content:
## Executive summary

> **NOTE**
>
> All the scopes described are estimated in FTE (Full Time Employee) valued at $200k per annum.

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) is an ongoing project that is already a few months old, and resources have initially been allocated to bootstrap its development. Given the core nature of [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) and in order to avoid becoming financially dependent on a single entity for its development, we are seeking **â‚³1.5M** of additional funding for the **second half of 2025**.

The table below breaks down the current/estimated effort, the fraction of resources already secured from other sources of funding, and the resources needed. It covers the whole of 2025.

| Scope                                            | Owner    | Estimated effort | Resources already secured | Resources needed |
| ---                                              | ---      | ---              | ---                       | ---              |
| Ledger                                           | Matthias | 2.5 FTEs         | 1 FTE                     | 1.5 FTEs         |
| Consensus and simulation                         | Arnaud   | 2.5 FTEs         | 1 FTE                     | 1.5 FTEs         |
| Networking                                       | Santiago | 1 FTE            | 1 FTE                     | 0 FTEs           |
| Ad-hoc Mercenaries                               | Pi       | 2.5 FTEs         | 0 FTEs                    | 2.5 FTEs         |
| Project Management, Public Relations & Marketing | Damien   | 0.5 FTEs         | 0 FTEs                    | 0.5 FTEs         |

The total resources without funding for 2025 adds up to **6 FTEs**. Considering this budget ask is only for **the second half of 2025**, it halves to `$600,000` (600K) once converted to USD (`$`). We then add a 25% contingency budget to cope with our optimistic bias: we are aware that our forecast is subject to underestimating complexity, overlooking challenges, and undervaluing the time and cost required to deliver.

With this contingency, we end up at **`$750,000` (750K)**. Finally, using a conservative conversion rate of 0.5 ADA (`â‚³`) per USD (`$`) at the date of the withdrawal, we formulate a budget of **`â‚³1,500,000` (1.5M)**.

> **NOTE**
>
> The Networking scope described in our [design documentation](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru/blob/main/engineering-decision-records/006-design-phase-documentation.md) is included in our proposal for reference but is already covered by a [Catalyst proposal](https://projectcatalyst.io/funds/12/cardano-open-developers/amaru-p2p-networking-component-by-txpipe). It is fully managed by Santiago.

## Administration of the budget

The [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) maintainer committee will ensure **direct administration** of the budget, assisted with **an on-chain smart contract** (developed in open source, still incomplete, but aimed to be done and fully audited by the time of the first withdrawal).

The fund management, responsibilities and remuneration of contributors will follow PRAGMA's legal framework provided in annex under [PRAGMA Maintainer Committee Framework](https://ipfs.io/ipfs/bafkreiabxyva5lfm6zztg7tnktxvvbbucljrce7hlrp4p6hropqzfaip3y).

In addition, the smart contract's role is to ensure that the expenditure of funds is done in accordance with the scope defined in this budget and authorized by the relevant scope owners.

We recognize the following capabilities of this contract:

1. **Standard withdrawal**: A scope owner asks other scope owners for money to be withdrawn from his scope.
2. **Contingency withdrawal**: A scope owner asks other scope owners to withdraw an amount from the contingency funds.
3. **Scope reconciliation**: A scope owner asks other scope owners for a change of ownership (or a reallocation of budget).
4. **Contingency refund/closing**: scope owners ask to send the leftovers from the contingency budget to be sent back to the Cardano treasury.
5. **Credential rotation**: In case of lost credentials or the departure of a scope owner, a mechanism allows the rotation of credentials to a new scope owner upon approval by all (5 out of 5) PRAGMA members (effectively capturing PRAGMA's board decision to appoint new maintainers).
6. **Failsafe**: In the extreme scenario where credentials would be irremediably lost, thus preventing any further decision, a failsafe mechanism allows all unconsumed funds to be sent back to the Cardano treasury.

## Reporting

#### Quarterly reports

Following [PRAGMA's Decision Record 006](https://github.com/pragma-org/PDRs/tree/main/PDR-0006-Project-Reporting), progress on [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) shall be **at least reported quarterly**. The content of [these reports](https://pragma.io/projects/amaru#quarterly-reports) is straightforward and includes the following:

- Problems that require board attention (infrastructure, trademarks, etc.)
- Project status (active, inactive, initiating, etc.)
- A changelog (last committer addition)
- Next planned steps (new releases, significant changes, etc.)
- Reflection & Performances

This recurrent interaction will provide an overview of the project with a long-term perspective and support the maintainers' committee in aligning priorities and identifying the next steps. The outcome of these reviews will be publicly available as documentation in [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru)'s GitHub repository.

#### Regular demos

Amaru is demo-driven. We strive to integrate early and provide runnable examples showcasing the latest features as the project is being developed. The cadence for these demos is around 4 to 6 weeks, as illustrated on the [existing track record](https://pragma.io/projects/amaru#demos).

We will naturally continue to **record and post demos regularly**.

## Constitutionality checklist

Being one of the first proposals of this nature ever submitted, it is easy to get things wrong. In an effort to convince ourselves of its constitutionality, we thought relevant to include a checklist of the points we cover and for each, our interpretation of the Cardano Constitution.

#### Purpose

- [x] This proposal is for work intended to enhance the security, decentralization and long-term sustainability of Cardano.

#### Article III.5: the process of on-chain governance

- [x] We have submitted this proposal in a standardized, legible format, which includes a URL and hash of all documented off-chain content. We believe our rationale to be detailed and sufficient. The proposal contains a title, abstract, reason for the proposal and relevant supporting materials.

#### Article IV.1: proposing budgets

- [x] This proposal accords with the provisions of this article as it is intended to cover the maintenance and future development of the Cardano Blockchain.

- [x] This proposal covers a shorter period than 73 epochs, which is permitted in this section of the Constitution, to match the Net-Change Limit period.

#### Article IV.2: funds administration

- [x] This proposal specifies an administrator in accordance with this provision. It also specifies an internal administration process using smart contracts and an off-chain overseeing committee, meeting the requirements of this clause, which requires a process that may include an administrator.

#### Article IV.3: Net-Change Limit

- [x] Being of â‚³1.5M and covering the second half of 2025, this proposal and the treasury withdrawals it would enable do not violate the currently agreed upon Net-Change Limit.

#### Article IV.4: Auditor

- [x] This proposal makes provisions for an auditor (covered by the _Ad-hoc mercenaries_ scope).

#### Guardrails

- [x] This proposal is subject to _TREASURY-04a_ in that it defines a Cardano blockchain ecosystem budget. It requires a threshold greater than 50% of the DReps' active voting stake to be considered approved and enable subsequent withdrawals pertaining to this budget.

# Conclusion

The [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) project represents a major step towards node diversity through the development of a modular, high-performance, and interoperable block-producing node for Cardano. Our approach, rooted in openness, innovation, and operational resilience, aims to deliver significant advancements in blockchain technology without compromising on security.

In addition to this budget, we provide a detailed document outlining:

- explicit assumptions about the project, the valuation and the scopes covered;
- comparisons to similar projects of developing blockchain nodes; and
- the methodology used for managing the project, its deliveries, its finance and its governance.

Through rigorous design and execution phases, we have outlined actionable scopes, realistic timelines, and comprehensive resource allocations. The detailed breakdown of scopes, funding and resources already secured reflects our commitment to transparency and efficiency. While we remain optimistic about our forecasts, we acknowledge the complexities involved and have incorporated contingencies to address unforeseen challenges.

More than a mere budget, this proposal is an invitation to collaborate and innovate together. The [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) project is ambitious yet achievable through the collective effort of our contributors and the broader Cardano community. By focusing on building, learning, and demonstrating tangible progress, [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) paves the way for a more resilient and decentralized Cardano ecosystem, ensuring long-term reliability and innovation.

Let's build the future of Cardano together.

meta.motivation:
## Who we are

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) is a multi-entity effort that currently sits under [PRAGMA](https://pragma.io): a member-based, not-for-profit open-source association for blockchain software projects. Five members with equal power currently drive PRAGMA's strategy and operations: Blink Labs, Cardano Foundation, dcSpark, Sundae Labs, and TxPipe. Each of them has a proven track record of building on Cardano and supporting our ecosystem.

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) itself is managed by an appointed maintainer committee in charge of different scopes. The current maintainer committee comprises of:

- [Arnaud Bailly](https://github.com/abailly) responsible for the consensus and simulation testing.
- [Matthias Benkort](https://github.com/ktorz) responsible for the ledger & overall architecture.
- [Pi Lanningham](https://github.com/Quantumplation) responsible for the ad hoc work and middleware integrations.
- [Santiago Carmuega](https://github.com/scarmuega) responsible for the p2p networking.
- [Damien Czapla](https://github.com/Dam-CZ) responsible for the project management, public relations & marketing.

Each member of the maintainer committee is in charge of a scope and has oversight on its delivery, which includes managing an associated budget.

## Why build another node

One of Cardano's key assets is its legendary robustness and stability, which is mainly attributed to the existing Haskell node, which has been working without significant disruption for about five years now (counting since the Byron reboot, circa February 2020).

So why bother with another node? The answer is, of course, plural:

#### 1. **Better resource usage**

Software is ultimately a collection of design decisions and trade-offs. Some of those trade-offs in the Haskell node have led to rather high resource usages (e.g., resident memory), thus leading to the creation of specific protocol parameters (e.g., min-utxo-value) as countermeasures to ensure resource usage remains somewhat bounded. Our analysis is that different (albeit acceptable) trade-offs would yield better resource usage.

#### 2. **Industry-grade observability**

Observability is challenging, and it is even more so when rolling your own solution. With [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru), we intend to embrace industry standards for monitoring, tracing, and logging to drastically enhance the user experience for operators seeking insights into their node's behaviour.

#### 3. **Enhanced interoperability**

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) being primarily written in Rust means that we can more easily leverage an existing and thriving ecosystem of blockchain solutions and aim at multiple target platforms (e.g. web-assembly, RISC-V). This opens up not only to a wide variety of potential contributors but also to many new use cases that are much harder (not to say unrealistic) to achieve with a Haskell node.

#### 4. **Higher-assurance & robustness**

Developing a new implementation of existing software means dissecting every part of the original implementation. Along the way, bugs and discrepancies with the specification are commonly found through conformance testing. Gaps in the documentation can also be identified and addressed. The development of [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) has already proven this on several occasions. In the long run, more node implementations can be a synonym for reduced development time by allowing all implementations to converge faster towards better designs and more robust implementations.

#### 5. **Decentralization**

In a world where Byzantine fault tolerance is at the centre and where decentralization is a paramount value, we believe that a single-node implementation presents a single point of failure and a central point of control. A new node not only increases the overall resilience of the network but also provides perspectives in terms of a roadmap and use cases.

---

With [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru), we believe that we can reconcile these goals while preserving Cardano's focus on security and robustness. Like Haskell, Rust is a statically typed language that provides strong compile-time guarantees and fine-grained memory management. Its ecosystem is also well-equipped for high assurance, making it a sane choice for implementing blockchain solutions.

In addition to this budget, we provide a detailed document outlining:

- explicit assumptions about the project, the valuation and the scopes covered;
- comparisons to similar projects of developing blockchain nodes; and
- the methodology used for managing the project, its deliveries, its finance and its governance.

Through rigorous design and execution phases, we have outlined actionable scopes, realistic timelines, and comprehensive resource allocations. The detailed breakdown of scopes, funding and resources already secured reflects our commitment to transparency and efficiency. While we remain optimistic about our forecasts, we acknowledge the complexities involved and have incorporated contingencies to address unforeseen challenges.

More than a mere budget, this proposal is an invitation to collaborate and innovate together. The [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) project is ambitious yet achievable through the collective effort of our contributors and the broader Cardano community. By focusing on building, learning, and demonstrating tangible progress, [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) paves the way for a more resilient and decentralized Cardano ecosystem, ensuring long-term reliability and innovation.

Let's build the future of Cardano together.

## Who we are

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) is a multi-entity effort that currently sits under [PRAGMA](https://pragma.io): a member-based, not-for-profit open-source association for blockchain software projects. Five members with equal power currently drive PRAGMA's strategy and operations: Blink Labs, Cardano Foundation, dcSpark, Sundae Labs, and TxPipe. Each of them has a proven track record of building on Cardano and supporting our ecosystem.

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) itself is managed by an appointed maintainer committee in charge of different scopes. The current maintainer committee comprises of:

- [Arnaud Bailly](https://github.com/abailly) responsible for the consensus and simulation testing.
- [Matthias Benkort](https://github.com/ktorz) responsible for the ledger & overall architecture.
- [Pi Lanningham](https://github.com/Quantumplation) responsible for the ad hoc work and middleware integrations.
- [Santiago Carmuega](https://github.com/scarmuega) responsible for the p2p networking.
- [Damien Czapla](https://github.com/Dam-CZ) responsible for the project management, public relations & marketing.

Each member of the maintainer committee is in charge of a scope and has oversight on its delivery, which includes managing an associated budget.

## Why build another node

One of Cardano's key assets is its legendary robustness and stability, which is mainly attributed to the existing Haskell node, which has been working without significant disruption for about five years now (counting since the Byron reboot, circa February 2020).

So why bother with another node? The answer is, of course, plural:

#### 1. **Better resource usage**

Software is ultimately a collection of design decisions and trade-offs. Some of those trade-offs in the Haskell node have led to rather high resource usages (e.g., resident memory), thus leading to the creation of specific protocol parameters (e.g., min-utxo-value) as countermeasures to ensure resource usage remains somewhat bounded. Our analysis is that different (albeit acceptable) trade-offs would yield better resource usage.

#### 2. **Industry-grade observability**

Observability is challenging, and it is even more so when rolling your own solution. With [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru), we intend to embrace industry standards for monitoring, tracing, and logging to drastically enhance the user experience for operators seeking insights into their node's behaviour.

#### 3. **Enhanced interoperability**

[Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) being primarily written in Rust means that we can more easily leverage an existing and thriving ecosystem of blockchain solutions and aim at multiple target platforms (e.g. web-assembly, RISC-V). This opens up not only to a wide variety of potential contributors but also to many new use cases that are much harder (not to say unrealistic) to achieve with a Haskell node.

#### 4. **Higher-assurance & robustness**

Developing a new implementation of existing software means dissecting every part of the original implementation. Along the way, bugs and discrepancies with the specification are commonly found through conformance testing. Gaps in the documentation can also be identified and addressed. The development of [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru) has already proven this on several occasions. In the long run, more node implementations can be a synonym for reduced development time by allowing all implementations to converge faster towards better designs and more robust implementations.

#### 5. **Decentralization**

In a world where Byzantine fault tolerance is at the centre and where decentralization is a paramount value, we believe that a single-node implementation presents a single point of failure and a central point of control. A new node not only increases the overall resilience of the network but also provides perspectives in terms of a roadmap and use cases.

---

With [Amaru](https://github.com/pragma-org/amaru), we believe that we can reconcile these goals while preserving Cardano's focus on security and robustness. Like Haskell, Rust is a statically typed language that provides strong compile-time guarantees and fine-grained memory management. Its ecosystem is also well-equipped for high assurance, making it a sane choice for implementing blockchain solutions.

opinions.summary: The Amaru Node Development 2025 proposal seeks â‚³1.5 million in funding for the second half of 2025 to develop Amaru, an open-source, Rust-based, alternative block-producing node for Cardano. The project is led by PRAGMA, a consortium of established Cardano ecosystem entities. The intended goal is to enhance Cardano's network resilience, decentralization, and performance by introducing client diversity, reducing reliance on the primary Haskell-based node, and attracting a wider pool of developers through Rust. This initiative aligns with Cardano's strategic priority of evolving its technical infrastructure, particularly in areas of core protocol robustness and developer ecosystem expansion, against a competitive landscape where network performance and decentralization are key differentiators.
opinions.myOpinion: I strongly support the Amaru Node Development 2025 proposal. It directly addresses a fundamental requirement for any mature blockchain: client diversity. This is not merely a 'nice-to-have' but a critical component for enhancing network security, resilience against bugs or attacks, and true decentralization, moving away from reliance on a single core client. The choice of Rust is forward-thinking, likely to expand Cardano's developer community and potentially bring performance benefits. PRAGMA's involvement lends significant credibility. The requested budget is modest for an undertaking of this importance and potential impact. While the technical challenge of maintaining multiple clients is real, it is a necessary complexity for a platform aspiring to be a global financial and social operating system. The benefits of increased robustness, reduced systemic risk, and a more vibrant developer ecosystem far outweigh the manageable costs and technical coordination overhead. This proposal aligns perfectly with Cardano's long-term strategic objectives of creating a secure, sustainable, and efficient blockchain, and investing in high-quality engineering for critical infrastructure like Amaru is paramount.

Maybe rather than tweeting about treasury spending at a high level, I can clarify what some of the spending is that I would actually vote YES for on-chain currently (ie not via off-chain processes, which Iâ€™m not a fan of), if asked to do so.

As always, please delegate to someone else if my approach is not in line with yours:

NCL
A reasonable NCL would in my mind ideally be below 150m, but to be pragmatic Iâ€™m willing to sign off on <= 200m. My reasons for this are well documented, but primarily relate to the emissions-price pressure-value add relationships.

Core dev
A reasonable proposal by IOG to keep delivering on critical roadmap items would get my instant support. In my view the one we have seen on gov tools ticks that box, if with a slightly hefty ask. Also assuming no surprises, Iâ€™d approve associated forks and changes. 

I am aware others besides IOG could do some of the work, but I think a safe approach in the first years of governance would be to only gradually diversify the work beyond IOG, rather than pull away from them immediately. Again, being conservative.

High impact cost efficient proposals
Cost efficient, high impact technology efforts by other, ideally proven, actors. Think Midgard, Starstream or alternative nodes for single digit millions of ADA. Willing to entertain all similar impact and cost efficient ones.

Orgs
Assorted spending for Intersect and similar orgs pushing Cardano forward, if the asks are reasonable and well documented / detailed. Smaller asks will naturally be an easier yes.

Catalyst and/or Intersect budget
A slimmed down version of Catalyst to capture a lot of the efforts others want to put forward. Catalyst is a system that is not perfect, but is improving (eg quadratic voting) and is the current best framework we have for such things. Intersect might complement this, but needs to prove itself.

Summary
This covers core tech, non core tech innovation, orgs and all the other proposals via Intersect/Catalyst.

I think at a high level it should in principle be possible to fit all the above into a NCL of 150m ADA, though that would require some frugality on the part of all participants.

My stance on governance is that it should be transparent and on-chain wherever possible. I am currently unsure whether the Intersect budget process is as robust as what we have in place with Catalyst, and in any case it would need to prove itself.

Therefore my preference would be to pull some of the tech related ones that I mentioned out of this process, and put them to a direct DRep vote fairly soon. Shrink down both Catalyst/Intersect budgets significantly and put them to a vote. Iâ€™ll likely support them.

@JaromirTesar 

Scalability and Funding - Plan is still the same.  Last I checked both Midgard and IOG teams are still making good progress on things, despite the fact that we have not withdrawn from the Cardano treasury in a very long time.  I don't think another 6 weeks while we pursue a better will slow progress meaningfully.

Catalyst Funding - I'm not aware of these ecosystem teams that are "fighting for survival".  Catalyst has already been funded up through F13.  And how would any of these projects know that they would be approved for funding anyways?  IMHO a 6-week delay is perfectly fine.

Flexibility of Governance - I'm aware that a new NCL can be passed that is lower.  However, I worry that once we have a high NCL passed, many of the top dReps who happen to have budget proposals will rigorously defend the high limit so that their proposals have a better chance.  Better to approve a low NCL and then raise it later if we have to IMHO.

Market Timing and Investment Windows - I don't think any of the budget proposals mentioned so far move the needle enough in a positive direction to be worth the ADA they are asking for.  What is the PMF we are trying to market?  What strategic initiatives other than ones in IOG's core proposal, Midgard, Starstream, Amaru, and Gerolamo are needed?  All of those combined are still less than 200M ADA.  Also, I support a stablecoin liquidity proposal, but it needs to be decoupled from Emurgo's omnibus proposal IMHO.

Checks and Balances - The issue here is not necessarily that dReps will want to spend up to the cap.  It's that budget proposers will.  We don't have enough visibility into ANY of the proposals' true costs.  Example:  Maybe with a 150M NCL, IOG might propose 50M for their core proposal.  With 350M NCL, there is enough room for them to ask for 100M first just to see if it passes.  We WANT budget proposers to be *LIMITED* by the NCL to get them to compete to lower costs.

Misuse Isnâ€™t Solved by NCL Alone - Agreed.  But IMHO lowering the NCL will cause proposers to increase the *quality* of their proposals in order to compete with other proposers for a slice of a smaller pie.

Selling Pressure and Timing - ADA is currently 5x below ATH.  I very much doubt that it will be on its way back down again 6 weeks from now.  In fact I think if we delay a little bit we'll be more likely to stretch the value of our ADA spent to go much further.

These are some of the main reasons I am strongly against approving a 350M NCL right now.

My Rationale for Budget Proposals

I supported 23 projects totaling 222.2M ADA. I voted NO for all others.

Number of supported projects across categories:

â€¢ Core: 17
â€¢ Research: 2
â€¢ Marketing & Innovation: 2
â€¢ Governance support: 2

The 3 largest projects I supported are IOG Core development, IO Research, and Catalyst. 

These 3 items account for 193M ADA.

I was hesitant to support IOG research. In the past, many academic papers have been published. We do not need all the research items on the list for next year. Now it is necessary to support implementation and the ecosystem more, which, in my opinion, is lagging behind research.

On the other hand, Cardano's success is largely based on research and quality implementation using formal methods. 

Not supporting research would be a step aside. Some of the things on the list may be implemented in the future.

My recommendation for next time is to create a separate proposal for each item instead of one proposal with many items. This also applies to Core development.

As I mentioned before, I consider Catalyst to be the place where most projects should apply for funding. That is why I support it.

During the review of Budget Proposals, I noticed that in many cases, only about 2-3 DReps voted. In the best case, about 10, rarely around 20. This is a very low participation.

Catalyst is not perfect, but it has been improved for several years, the team is experienced, and it is a battle-tested tool. ADA holders are already familiar with the system. Moreover, further improvements are planned.

At this point, I see no reason to replace Catalyst with Budget Proposals.

My other recommendation is that IOG should submit separate GAs for their proposals once the NCL is approved. This will avoid the situation where DReps vote on a GA with many other items in one GA.

I only used 29M ADA to support the other 23 projects. 

These are projects that, in my opinion, the ecosystem desperately needs.

I consider Midgard, Starstream, Hydra, ZK Rollups, an alternative Cardano node, integration with Bitcoin, and several others to be must-have projects.

If I came across multiple similar proposals, I preferred open-source projects and entities that are well-known to the community or have delivered a project that is still in use today.

I would like to emphasize that if I voted NO, it could mean:

â€¢ I don't like the project. It shouldn't be funded from Treasury (or Catalyst).

â€¢ I like the project, and it should apply for funding from Catalyst.

In general, I think that projects with ambitions to be commercially successful should look for other sources of funding. 

I don't like it when a risky business is funded from the Treasury, and in case of success, the profit is privatized.

If projects apply for Treasury funding, they should have a strategy on how to return part of the profit back to the community in case of success.

Furthermore, I think that if it is a startup, the team cannot expect that devs will be paid the same salaries as IOG devs. Part of the risk must be borne by the team, not just Treasury.

Some projects do not have a commercial character, for example, libraries, dev tools, etc. We should identify these projects, evaluate their benefits, and possibly support them.

The last major project I supported was the Marketing Strategy from the Cardano Foundation. This also includes the Cardano Summit.

In general, I do not want to support projects from founding entities that hold Genesis coins and have not spent them yet. The Cardano Foundation is such an entity, which was negatively reflected in the last Catalyst Fund.

On the other hand, this proposal was the best in the marketing category. The Cardano Foundation supports many activities in the ecosystem. CF wants to remain active in the long term and support building the ecosystem, for which it needs to secure funding.

The costs of the Cardano Summit and other marketing activities can be high. I would not like to risk that if their proposal is not approved, the next Cardano Summit will not be organized. The crypto industry could perceive this negatively.

I have only supported a single proposal from Intersect regarding the budget for open-source development. They are asking for 5.8M ADA.

New proposals appear every day, so my decision may not be final.  I may make changes.

My DRep ID:
drep1km69g7ksf8t5g0h9d9tkrcd2tezxelx0wtr76rv2mrkl5nzd6v3

â€¢ I don't like the project. It shouldn't be funded from Treasury (or Catalyst).

â€¢ I like the project, and it should apply for funding from Catalyst.

In general, I think that projects with ambitions to be commercially successful should look for other sources of funding. 

I don't like it when a risky business is funded from the Treasury, and in case of success, the profit is privatized.

If projects apply for Treasury funding, they should have a strategy on how to return part of the profit back to the community in case of success.

Furthermore, I think that if it is a startup, the team cannot expect that devs will be paid the same salaries as IOG devs. Part of the risk must be borne by the team, not just Treasury.

Some projects do not have a commercial character, for example, libraries, dev tools, etc. We should identify these projects, evaluate their benefits, and possibly support them.

The last major project I supported was the Marketing Strategy from the Cardano Foundation. This also includes the Cardano Summit.

In general, I do not want to support projects from founding entities that hold Genesis coins and have not spent them yet. The Cardano Foundation is such an entity, which was negatively reflected in the last Catalyst Fund.

tweets.text:
âœ… I voted YES for the Amaru project. 

My Rationale

Node diversity is critical for decentralization and network resilience. When multiple independent teams build node software, it reduces reliance on a single entity, such as IOG in the case of Cardano. 

It minimizes the systemic risks associated with monoculture software development.

One of the core promises of blockchain networks is high availability, including strong resistance to attacks and censorship. 

While no system can guarantee 100% uptime, having multiple node implementations increases the networkâ€™s robustness. If a bug or vulnerability is present in one version, others may remain unaffected, limiting potential damage.

Encouraging additional node implementations also deepens understanding of the protocol. As more developers build and maintain nodes, they contribute to refining the protocol specification, surfacing ambiguities, and improving long-term maintainability. 

This also supports future clients by setting a clearer and more battle-tested standard.

For comparison, Bitcoin is largely dependent on a single implementation: Bitcoin Core. While there are alternatives (e.g., btcd, Bitcoin Knots), they are rarely used, making the network heavily reliant on a single development team. 

This centralization becomes especially visible during governance disputes, such as those surrounding the use of the OP_RETURN opcode and Ordinals.

In contrast, Ethereum has multiple actively maintained implementations for both its consensus and execution layers. These include clients like Geth, Nethermind, Besu, Erigon (execution), and Prysm, Lighthouse, Teku, Nimbus (consensus). 

This diversity has strengthened Ethereum's decentralization and made the network more resilient to bugs and performance issues in any single client.

Node diversity, however, comes with challenges. 

Divergent implementations can lead to consensus bugs or temporary chain splits if not carefully tested. 

Coordinated testnets and protocol-level specification clarity are essential to mitigate these risks. 

Protocol upgrades may also take longer, as all implementations must integrate and validate changes, such as the upcoming Ouroboros Leios, which both IOG and Amaru nodes will need to support.

Sustained funding is another consideration. 

Maintaining multiple full node implementations is resource-intensive and will likely require long-term support from the Cardano Treasury. 

However, the cost is justified by the increased decentralization, security, and community participation that such diversity brings.

The Amaru team's funding request is reasonable, especially compared to the budgets that IOG requires. 

The team includes respected developers from within the Cardano ecosystem and is supported by several reputable entities. Their proposed Rust-based node implementation would be a serious alternative to IOGâ€™s Haskell-based Cardano node, marking a crucial step forward for ecosystem resilience.

This initiative strengthens decentralization, improves protocol robustness, and represents a healthy evolution of the Cardano network.

English.title: 2025 Cardano NCL
English.abstract: The Cardano Constitution, at Article IV, Section 3, requires that before withdrawal of Treasury funds, the community must have established a Net Change Limit (NCL). This means passing a NCL in a formal on-chain governance info action. The NCL represents the maximum amount of ada which may be withdrawn from the Cardano Treasury in a given period. It is a guardrail which, by definition in the Cardano Blockchain Ecosystem Constitution Definitions referenced below, protects the sustainability of the Cardano Treasury by preventing excessive withdrawals.
English.content:
Article IV, Section I of the Cardano Constitution states: â€œThe Cardano Community may propose one aggregate budget or multiple budgets for the Cardano Blockchain ecosystem. Such budgets are expected to cover not less than a period of 73 epochs (approximately one calendar year) but nothing shall prevent the Cardano Community from proposing budgets for shorter or longer time periods (emphasis added).

At this time, there are approximately eight (8) months left of 2025. It will take at least 30â€“60 more days to pass a budget. We believe the NCL for 2025, covering the period from the start of Epoch 532 to the end of Epoch 604, should be 200M ada.

There are several reasons for this. Members of the Cardano community have generated models showing 350M+/- ada per calendar year was added to the Cardano Treasury in 2024 and therefore, setting NCL at 350M ada preserves the Treasury principal. Regardless of whether such models are accurate, we believe that the community should not set NCL so high at first. There is no reason not to continue to grow the Treasury while the community sorts out its priorities for development and its funding processes.

This NCL guides the first budget â€˜experimentâ€™ of the first ever on-chain Cardano governance. The community has never before been solely responsible for payment to core Cardano developers and has little first-hand knowledge of those expenses. The community is still working out budget processes and evaluating proposed budgets as well as determining appropriate audit and administration methods. For the 2025 year, we should be cautious, while at the same time, permitting use of Treasury funds to continue core maintenance, enhance scaling and other goals. We need to evaluate the impacts to the ecosystem of this funding, the administration of the budget, and the effect of selling 200M ada in a short period of time. We need to let our budget processes mature and to understand risks they may pose to Treasury and the Cardano protocol. A new NCL can and should be set for 2026 after the community has more experience behind it. This may result in an increase, or a decrease, in the limit set in future NCLs.

This NCL shall be applied to budget actions and treasury withdrawal actions to ensure compliance with Article IV of the Cardano Constitution and the Treasury Withdrawal Guardrails specified in Appendix I.

A vote in favor of this proposal shall indicate agreement with the proposed NCL, allowing for the submission of budget info actions and treasury withdrawal governance actions. The maximum amount that can be withdrawn from the treasury during the specified period shall not exceed the total sum outlined herein.

The provisions set forth in the Cardano Constitution state that the approval of a NCL requires a threshold of greater than 50% of the active voting DRep stake. Therefore, this NCL will be considered passed if it is greater than 50+1 lovelace%.

In the event of conflict, this NCL supersedes any prior NCL covering all or part of calendar year 2025.

cons: A 200M NCL may be too restrictive to adequately fund critical technical advancements (e.g., Leios, Hydra, L2s) and broader ecosystem growth simultaneously for the remainder of 2025.

pros: Establishes fiscal prudence for Cardano's first major on-chain budgeting period, safeguarding Treasury sustainability while governance processes mature.

opinions.summary: The proposal suggests establishing a Net Change Limit (NCL) of 200M ada for the Cardano Treasury for the remaining approximately eight months of 2025, specifically from the start of Epoch 532 to the end of Epoch 604. This initiative is framed as a cautious initial step into fully on-chain treasury governance. The intended goal is to allow the Treasury to accumulate resources while the Cardano community develops and refines its processes for budgeting, funding allocation, and auditing. Proposers acknowledge that Treasury inflows in 2024 might have been around 350M ada but advocate for a lower NCL at the outset to mitigate risks associated with the community's relative inexperience in managing core developer payments and large-scale ecosystem funding. The plan is to gather insights from this initial period to inform a more experienced-based NCL for 2026. This conservative fiscal approach is contextualized by Cardano's broader strategic objectives, which include significant advancements in its technical infrastructure (such as the Leios upgrade, Hydra protocol, and Layer 2 scaling solutions), fostering ecosystem development to maintain competitiveness with other leading blockchain platforms, and maturing its decentralized governance model under the Voltaire era.
opinions.myOpinion: The proposal for a 200M ada NCL for the remainder of 2025 reflects a commendable desire for caution as Cardano transitions to more decentralized, on-chain treasury management. However, when weighed against Cardano's primary strategic objectiveâ€”the continued evolution of its technical infrastructure, including critical initiatives like the Leios upgrade, Hydra protocol, and Layer 2 scaling solutions â€”and the explicit goal to 'pay a premium for good engineering', this NCL appears potentially too restrictive. Community feedback frequently highlights that funding requirements for core development (e.g., IOG) could consume a very large portion, if not most, of this 200M ada limit. This would leave minimal resources for other vital technical advancements from diverse ecosystem contributors, broader L2 scaling efforts, DeFi growth, and new project incubationâ€”all essential for Cardano's long-term success and competitiveness. While prudence is essential, under-resourcing strategic technical priorities could hinder Cardano's trajectory more significantly than the risks associated with a slightly larger, yet still carefully managed, initial NCL. The consequences of implementing a 200M NCL might include slowed technical progress and a constrained ecosystem, potentially requiring reactive governance actions to adjust the limit upwards. Not implementing it (or having no NCL) would halt constitutional treasury withdrawals. Considering these factors, I **oppose** the 200M ada NCL proposal for the specified ~8-month period in 2025 as it may not adequately serve Cardano's strategic technical imperatives. A moderately higher NCL, perhaps in the 250M-275M ada range for this partial year, could offer a more balanced approach: still emphasizing fiscal caution and allowing governance processes to mature, but providing more realistic support for the critical technical evolution and ecosystem development that Cardano requires to achieve its long-term vision of becoming a leading blockchain platform. This should be coupled with rigorous, transparent, and milestone-driven budget approval and oversight mechanisms.

ðŸ”¥ #Cardano Governance Update ðŸ”¥

What's at stake for the future of Cardano: The Update, The Constitution, the Treasury, and the Budgets.

The Plomin Hard Fork 

This update will be the final step to full participation in Cardano Governance as designed by CIP-1694. Expect to see the Plomin Hard Fork submitted on chain very soon.  A few months ago, when the Chang Hard Fork was enacted, it activated the Governance Bootstrap Phase which allowed Delegated Representatives (DReps) to register on-chain and established the Constitutional Committee (CC) to vote on Governance Actions (GAs) along with Stake Pool Operators (SPOs).  However, governance was limited.

Once the Plomin Hard Fork passes the DReps will gain full voting power, not just the ability to vote on Info Actions (visit https://t.co/aRWErA7Waj for a guide to the different type of Governance Actions).  This means that the Cardano Community will be able to update the Cardano Constitution and withdraw funds from the Cardano Treasury.

Why do we care about establishing the Constitution and withdrawing funds from the Treasury?  Well, quite frankly, it's because Cardano has grown up and we have to start living on our own now.  When Cardano was launched in 2017 the pioneering entities were given grants of Ada (about 20% of the total supply) in order to deliver us a decentralized ecosystem that the we, the users, could govern ourselves.  Now that we have the power of governance we need to firmly set the ground rules that protects the rights of everyone who interacts in the Cardano ecosystem, we need to collectively decide on the future development roadmap of Cardano, and we need to have a way to pay for it!

The Constitution

The past few months have been a historic time for Cardano as the community engaged in a deliberative process to draft a new Constitution.  While an Interim Constitution had been established with the Chang Hard Fork that document was written with an intentional plan for replacement.  @IntersectMBO with the help of @InputOutputHK, @Cardano_CF, @emurgo_io, and countless community contributors held 63 workshops across the world where Delegates for a Constitutional Convention were selected. These Delegates participated in synthesis sessions to review the language of the proposed new constitution that had been drafted by the Cardano Civics Committee of Intersect, solicited community feedback on proposed changes, and then came together in Buenos Aires and Nairobi to debate and approve a final draft.

All that being said, this new Constitution is not yet approved!  In a decentralized ecosystem of blockchain technology like Cardano, the establishment of a new Constitution cannot be valid until the Ada holders, as represented by their DReps, vote in favor.  Once the Plomin Hard Fork has passed (fingers crossed!) the community will be able to consider a Governance Action to ratify the new Constitution.  We can continue to operate under the Interim Constitution, if we must, but it would be far preferable to move to a new Constitution that came from a community review process as soon as possible.

The Treasury

One of the most unique and powerful aspects of Cardano is that we have a common Treasury to provide for the operation, maintenance, and future development of the blockchain ecosystem. Each Epoch, 20% of the Rewards Pool (transaction fees and monetary expansion) goes to the Treasury instead while the rest goes to Staking Rewards.

Because this Treasury comes out of the Staking Rewards that would otherwise go to the members of the Cardano Community, it is essential that the fund be safeguarded.  That is why the Interim Constitution and the proposed Constitution both specify that a Net Change Limit must be approved through a Governance Info Action before any Treasury Withdrawals are made.

The Net Change Limit that is adopted by the community must define how much Ada can be spent out of the Treasury in a certain amount of time.  For practical purposes (at least as we start), this will most likely mean that we decide how much to spend in 73 epochs (a calendar year).  Because the CC is obligated to vote down any Treasury Withdrawal GA that does not fit within the established Net Change Limit, we must make sure that this value fits within our planned spending for the year and allows for contingencies that may come up.  There is a fine balance to be struck!

The Budgets

In addition to the Net Change Limit, the Interim Constitution and the proposed Constitution specify that the no Treasury Withdrawal GA can pass unless it fits within a Budget that has been approved by the Cardano community through a vote by DReps.  The CC must also vote on any proposed budget to ensure that proposed spending does not violate the Constitution.

With text of the Constitution, the Budget requirements are purposefully flexible to give the Cardano Community options to fund the decentralized ecosystem.  While the Interim Constitution simply says there must be some Budget in place, the proposed Constitution is a bit more explicit in describing how each Budget must have an Administrator to ensure Treasury Withdrawals are properly spent.  This Administrator could be a person, an institution, or a smart contract, and I expect we will see this practice evolve over time.

While anyone on Cardano can propose a budget, a large amount of community effort has been focused on working with @IntersectMBO to propose a comprehensive budget to support Cardano in 2025.  This process is nearing completion and the Budget Committee has stated they will be ready to report their proposal to the community soon.  They have already held numerous community meetings describing the process and soliciting feedback.

One of the keys to Intersect's approach will be to ensure that there is no single person in charge of the administration of funds.  The Budgets that Intersect will propose will give Administrator responsibilities to various committees of Intersect that are run by Cardano community members.  Again, we are seeking to balance the benefits of decentralization with the recognition that empowering people to act for the greater good is the best way to move a process forward.

The Timeline & Conclusion

Now that we have a clear picture on what needs to happen for Cardano to move forward, we can discuss the timing of each action. Each time a Governance Action is proposed the Cardano community has 6 Epochs (30 days) to vote on it and then it takes one Epoch for the GA to take effect.  While most actions can pass early (if they get the necessary threshold of Yes votes) it is best to make a conservative estimate that the vote will run the full length of time possible.

If the Plomin Hard Fork GA is submitted on December 21 (the beginning of Cardano Epoch 529) we are looking at probable enactment on January 24 (Epoch 536).  Then, and only then, can we reasonably submit the Constitution for ratification.  The Treasury will also be unlocked and DReps can consider Treasury Withdrawal Governance Actions.

While the Treasury will be unlocked on January 24, provided that the Plomin Hard Fork GA passes, the CC will not approve any actions the DReps take to withdraw funds unless the Net Change Limit and at least one Budget have been approved.  That means that we will need to have the DReps and CC vote on Governance Info Actions to approve these items before any Treasury Withdrawals are submitted.

Fortunately, because DReps are able to vote for Info Actions right now, we do not need to wait for the Plomin Hard Fork to be enacted to begin these discussions.  The community can consider and vote on the Hard Fork, the Net Change Limit, and the proposed Budgets within the same window of time.  We have a lot of important issues to figure out but I am confident that we can work through them and show how decentralized governance can make a Top-10 Blockchain ecosystem not just function but thrive!

If you're a Blockchain Governance nerd like me, you've probably been nodding along as you read this and have been along for the ride up to this point.  If you're just getting into it and have read this far, I hope you'll join us for the next big step of the journey.  Either way, get some rest over the holidays, because January is going to be an exciting time for Cardano!

I announce that I intend to vote NO âŒon the governance action regarding the Net Change Limit for 2025 and 2026 in a few days.

ðŸš¨Please redelegate to another Cardano DRep if you wish that your stake counts towards a YES or ABSTAIN vote. ðŸš¨

- I have read the governance info action and I welcome its submission and the reasonable proposal that was put forward.
- I was originally inclined to vote YES, as we could face a period of analysis paralysis and the proposal seemed reasonable enough.
- I continued to follow the debate about the proposed governance info action "Set 2025 Net Change Limit of 300M ADA, 2026 Net Change Limit of 250M ADA".
- However, Cardano constitution does not explicitly define what is a Net Change Limit (NCL). Different participants have shown that they may have different understandings of the meaning. Some do not understand it. Does NCL include inflows and/or outflows into the treasury? How is NCL calculated exactly? The precise definition is unclear. Voting YES until this is cleared up in the constitution could result in poorly understood actions leading to unexpected consequences. This could jeopardize the stability of the Cardano monetary system. Of course, this not the fault of the proposers of this governance action. Their governance action helped to uncover this lack of precision in the Cardano constitution.
- The proposed governance action proposes setting the NCL close to the maximum projected inflows into the treasury. The maximum inflows are forecast to be 300M ADA in 2025 and 265M ADA in 2026. On the face of it, it is a relatively reasonable proposal to set the NCL to 300M ADA in 2025 and to 250M ADA in 2026.
- I do not think there is a need to set the NCL for 2026 at this moment in time. Although I welcome the idea of making it no higher than the inflows.
- Through this vote rationale I am also signaling that even if I do vote for a motion that sets the NCL to 300M ADA in 2025 and 250M ADA in 2026, it is not likely that I will vote for a Cardano annual budget and withdrawals that are as high as 300M ADA in 2025.
- Hence, I would prefer to see a proposal of a smaller NCL for 2025, probably 200-250M ADA. This will help focus the budgetary discussion on essentials.
- I also have to consider that Catalyst has been allocated 150M ADA for three funds in 2024. Not all of this has been disbursed as the Catalyst payments are milestone based and some Catalyst projects give up or just stall. Many payments still take place in 2025. The proposed NCL for 2025 of 300M ADA is twice the size of what was allocated to Catalyst in 2024.
- I also agree with suggestions that I think the Net Change Limit (NCL) could be linked to or calculated based on net treasury revenue for the previous 73 epochs.  This was proposed by Cardano DRep CardanoYoda: "If the NCL is set to, for example, 80% and Treasury revenue for the last year was 300M ADA, 240M ADA could be spent." The advantages of this solution are that it is not necessary to project future Treasury revenue. A similar idea was floated by Cardano community member Max Capacity in the TECH SPO Discord: " Monte Carlo simulations for estimating forward value? There's just so much variability and it opens it up to second guessing and even more wasted time and energy. Just use the prior year and no one can argue anything and you have certainty on Dec 31 reach year. I also like the last 73 epoch idea because it then means you don't have to stick to the calendar periodicity. Maybe the budget runs June to July. "

Just voted NO âŒ on proposed gov info action to set NCL for 2025 and 2026. 

Rationale:

While there seem to be some open questions surrounding the definition of NCL in the Cardano constitution, I will sidestep that issue here. 
I vote against the proposed governance action because it wishes to set a Net Change Limit for two years in one swoop. 
This not only weakens the chances for the motion to pass, but it also makes it less clear what needs to be corrected if the motion fails. 
Future proposers should probably focus on proposing a Net Change Limit for one year, due to the slow nature of decentralized governance. 
Finally, I was not convinced by the motion that there is an absolute need to set an NCL for 2026 this early, as it is March 2025. A lot can happen between now and 2026, setting a 2026 limit seems premature - hence a bad precedent. 
I welcome the attempt by the proposers to highlight a need for conservative spending, by roughly limiting the NCL to the volume of of Cardano annual treasury inflows in 2025 and 2026.

Let me explain the Net Change Limit in context.

The Net Change Limit (NCL) serves as a prevention against excessive withdrawal of ADA from the Treasury.

The NCL defines the maximum amount of ADA that can be withdrawn from the Treasury in a given period. This period is usually one year, which corresponds to 72 epochs.

The NCL can be defined as the amount of ADA for a given period. An alternative approach would be to express it as a percentage of Treasury revenue for a given past period.

For example, as 80% of Treasury revenue for the last 72 epochs.

It is up to the community to choose what they like best. 

The first approach is more flexible because it is necessary to approve the NCL every year. The second approach could work in the long term without annual approval.

The NCL must be approved through governance action before it is possible to submit a proposal for withdrawal of ADA from the Treasury.

The NCL applies to all withdrawals from the Treasury in a given period.

Once the total number of ADA individually withdrawn from the Treasury reaches the defined NCL, further withdrawals exceeding the limit will become unconstitutional.

There is currently no NCL defined, so withdrawals are not possible.

There are two governance actions regarding NCL for next year.

The first one submitted by the community tries to set the NCL at 300M ADA. The second one from intersect sets 350M ADA.

There are currently 1.71B ADA in the Cardano Treasury.

Revenues to the treasury consist of monetary expansion and fees. Fees are currently almost negligible. 

Most of the revenues consist of monetary expansion, i.e. the gradual transfer of ADA from the reserve to the Treasury.

There are currently 7.2B ADA in the reserve. The reserve is used to pay out staking rewards and deposit ADA into the Treasury.

The reserve is gradually trending towards 0. With each subsequent epoch, the reserve is decreasing. 

Treasury revenues will depend on fees and possibly other alternative revenues in the future.

NCL is to prevent the rapid depletion of the Treasury, as ADA should be used to grow the ecosystem. 

By this you can imagine a payment to IOG for the delivery of Ouroboros Leios, but also, for example, minting stablecoins. Basically, anything that the community approves.

There is a consensus that expenses should not be higher than Treasury revenues. NCL should reflect this. However, it is theoretically possible to approve NCL higher than Treasury revenues.

An important aspect of NCL is the direct negative impact on the market price of ADA. Entities that receive ADA from the Treasury can sell coins on the market to cover their living expenses.

Selling pressure can harm SPOs and stakers.

Ultimately, this can also have a negative impact on Treasury, because if the market price of ADA is low in a bear market, it will be necessary to sell even more ADA in the coming years.

It is necessary to find a balance between the potential long-term positive impact of the investment and the medium-term market price of ADA.

NCL does not mean that we have to spend a defined maximum. It is possible to approve an NCL of 350M ADA, but still, only 200M ADA can be approved in total spending in a given period.

NCL is only an insurance against exceeding the limit. 

More important are individual withdrawals. Each of them must be justified and we must be sure that the investment will have a positive impact on the ecosystem from the long-term perspective.

There is a consensus that expenses should not be higher than Treasury revenues. NCL should reflect this. However, it is theoretically possible to approve NCL higher than Treasury revenues.

An important aspect of NCL is the direct negative impact on the market price of ADA. Entities that receive ADA from the Treasury can sell coins on the market to cover their living expenses.

Selling pressure can harm SPOs and stakers.

Ultimately, this can also have a negative impact on Treasury, because if the market price of ADA is low in a bear market, it will be necessary to sell even more ADA in the coming years.

It is necessary to find a balance between the potential long-term positive impact of the investment and the medium-term market price of ADA.

NCL does not mean that we have to spend a defined maximum. It is possible to approve an NCL of 350M ADA, but still, only 200M ADA can be approved in total spending in a given period.

NCL is only an insurance against exceeding the limit. 

More important are individual withdrawals. Each of them must be justified and we must be sure that the investment will have a positive impact on the ecosystem from the long-term perspective.

Early voting Intention announcement on: "2025 Net Change Limit" governance info action: âŒ

ðŸš¨If you are delegating to me, please redelegate to someone who wants to vote YES or ABSTAIN ðŸš¨

I welcome the proposed Net Change Limit proposal. The proposers have stated that from January 5th, 2024, Epoch 459, through December 30th, Epoch 531, the actual total income into the Cardano Treasury was 335,957,093 ada.

The proposed NCL is 350M ada. This is roughly 14M ada higher than the total income in the Cardano Treasury for 2024. I welcome the proposed reference to modelling and the reference to a previous period for which we have data. 

The motion uses modelling of ADA inflow for the previous year as the main basis for approving an NCL. It is indeed one of the factors that must be considered.
 
What I am missing in this proposal - as it proposes a relatively large NCL - is even a minor economic analysis of how approvals of different NCLs could impact the valuation of ADA. An NCL of 350M ADA is sending a signal to the market. What is this signal? 

How does it compare to previous signals? If we do not have the data, is there room for a prediction at least?
With the lack of this economic/monetary analysis, we are left to speculate. My feeling is that NCL approvals in the future will become defining moments that shape the ADA exchange rate vs the USD. It is a signal how much ADA could be released - a signal approved by the majority of DReps. 

The approval of a large NCL could have an immediate price impact on the value of ADA, thus diminishing the purchase power of the 350M ADA. Before the budget elements are approved. 

After approving a large NCL, the budgetary discussions will probably take place in the shadow of a lower ADA/USD exchange rate. Thus we might be forced by the market to push an annual budget towards the top limit of the NCL. We could create a self-fulfilling prophesy. 

The problem I see with a very large first year NCL is that our budgetary and governance processes are the weakest and most inefficient in the first year. Our ability to audit, prevent waste and abuse are questionable. A lower NCL would focus minds.

Without a monetary/economic analysis or forecast, I would consider voting for a NCL in the 200-250M ADA in 2025 (depending on the text of the NCL proposal) as it would give a better signal to the market about our intentions to balance the development of the system and the intention to safeguard the value of ADA and Cardano's Top 10 position. Especially, as our abilities to manage the potential spending of so much ADA in the early days of decentralized governance are the lowest. 

I see this conservative approach as something that protects the interests of ADA holders and stakers. 

Best practice: We SHOULD approve the closest NCL to the actual budget that we want as DReps. By approving a much larger NCL we will be devaluing the ada currency BEFORE any budget is approved and before the contractors receive the ADA. Effectively crippling ourselves unnecessarily. 

If the intention is to approve a lower budget than 350M ada as some (many?) DReps seem to have indicated, then to preserve the value of that ada for those who will receive it, the best thing we can do is to vote for an NCL that is closest to that intended 2025 budget total.

Maybe rather than tweeting about treasury spending at a high level, I can clarify what some of the spending is that I would actually vote YES for on-chain currently (ie not via off-chain processes, which Iâ€™m not a fan of), if asked to do so.

As always, please delegate to someone else if my approach is not in line with yours:

NCL
A reasonable NCL would in my mind ideally be below 150m, but to be pragmatic Iâ€™m willing to sign off on <= 200m. My reasons for this are well documented, but primarily relate to the emissions-price pressure-value add relationships.

Core dev
A reasonable proposal by IOG to keep delivering on critical roadmap items would get my instant support. In my view the one we have seen on gov tools ticks that box, if with a slightly hefty ask. Also assuming no surprises, Iâ€™d approve associated forks and changes. 

I am aware others besides IOG could do some of the work, but I think a safe approach in the first years of governance would be to only gradually diversify the work beyond IOG, rather than pull away from them immediately. Again, being conservative.

High impact cost efficient proposals
Cost efficient, high impact technology efforts by other, ideally proven, actors. Think Midgard, Starstream or alternative nodes for single digit millions of ADA. Willing to entertain all similar impact and cost efficient ones.

Orgs
Assorted spending for Intersect and similar orgs pushing Cardano forward, if the asks are reasonable and well documented / detailed. Smaller asks will naturally be an easier yes.

Catalyst and/or Intersect budget
A slimmed down version of Catalyst to capture a lot of the efforts others want to put forward. Catalyst is a system that is not perfect, but is improving (eg quadratic voting) and is the current best framework we have for such things. Intersect might complement this, but needs to prove itself.

Summary
This covers core tech, non core tech innovation, orgs and all the other proposals via Intersect/Catalyst.

I think at a high level it should in principle be possible to fit all the above into a NCL of 150m ADA, though that would require some frugality on the part of all participants.

My stance on governance is that it should be transparent and on-chain wherever possible. I am currently unsure whether the Intersect budget process is as robust as what we have in place with Catalyst, and in any case it would need to prove itself.

Therefore my preference would be to pull some of the tech related ones that I mentioned out of this process, and put them to a direct DRep vote fairly soon. Shrink down both Catalyst/Intersect budgets significantly and put them to a vote. Iâ€™ll likely support them.

As a DRep, Iâ€™ve not yet voted on the current GA proposal to set the 2025 Net Change Limit (NCL) at 350 million ADA. One key reason Iâ€™m holding off is in anticipation of an alternative proposal that sets a lower NCLâ€”something more reasonable and sustainable for our first treasury budget cycle.

We arrived at a second proposal because the first included multiple steep increases. While the second addressed some concerns, it also introduced new complexities, leaving many DRepsâ€”myself includedâ€”in a difficult position.

It feels as though there's pressure to accept the second proposal simply because the first failed. But that mindset is flawed. Just because one proposal doesn't pass doesnâ€™t mean the next one, regardless of its flaws, should be accepted by default.

I believe 350M ADA is too high. My position is that a more responsible range would be between 150M and 200M ADA. As our first ever annual budget, we must start with modest, realistic figures and scale up based on evidence of impact, efficiency, and community feedback.

Yes, the NCL is a ceiling and not a guarantee of expenditureâ€”but human nature and institutional behavior often aim for the ceiling once itâ€™s in place. Approving 350M now could set the precedent for even higher future budgets, regardless of whether the funds are effectively used.

I believe the community deserves a third, more balanced proposal. Itâ€™s overdueâ€”and we need it this week.

Letâ€™s set a strong foundation for treasury governance. One rooted in accountability, scalability, and community consensus.

#CardanoCommunity #Cardanogovernance #DReps

tweets.text:
Questions for those voting NO on NCL = 350M ADA.

I respect the decision of those who vote NO and understand the rationale behind it. 

However, I believe it's worth carefully examining the potential consequences of such a stanceâ€”or at the very least, identifying if Iâ€™m overlooking something critical.

â€¢ Scalability and Funding: What is your alternative plan for ensuring the scalability of Cardano? Without the approved NCL, how do you expect teams like IOG or Midgard to cover ongoing development costs? Are you not concerned that this might slow down or even stall progress?

â€¢ Catalyst Funding: The next Catalyst round is on hold, awaiting a budget decision. Essential ecosystem teams are already at risk of fighting for survival. Is that an acceptable trade-off?

â€¢ Flexibility of Governance: Are you aware that a new Governance Action (GA) proposing a lower NCL can be submitted at any time? If so, why is NCL = 350M ADA perceived as so threatening?

â€¢ Market Timing and Investment Windows: The current bull market wonâ€™t last forever. Now is the ideal time to mint stablecoins, run marketing campaigns, and support strategic initiatives. By the end of 2025, it may be too late. Isnâ€™t it prudent to act while conditions are favorable?

â€¢ Checks and Balances: Why assume total spending will automatically reach the NCL cap? DReps are tasked with voting on the budget and treasury withdrawals. ADA holders can monitor their choices and redelegate if necessary. Isnâ€™t this an effective safeguard?

â€¢ Misuse Isnâ€™t Solved by NCL Alone: Even under a lower NCL, poorly designed or fraudulent projects may still get approved. Isnâ€™t it more productive to focus on improving the quality of Budget Proposals rather than capping available funds?

â€¢ Selling Pressure and Timing: Teams would receive a higher USD value if they sell ADA near an all-time high. While that scenario may still play out, the crypto market is notoriously unpredictable. Spreading withdrawals over time reduces sell pressure. Does it really make sense to delay spending until the end of 2025?

I welcome constructive dialogue. My intent is not to polarize but to ensure that all dimensions of this decision are fully considered.

tweets.text:
@JaromirTesar 

Scalability and Funding - Plan is still the same.  Last I checked both Midgard and IOG teams are still making good progress on things, despite the fact that we have not withdrawn from the Cardano treasury in a very long time.  I don't think another 6 weeks while we pursue a better will slow progress meaningfully.

Catalyst Funding - I'm not aware of these ecosystem teams that are "fighting for survival".  Catalyst has already been funded up through F13.  And how would any of these projects know that they would be approved for funding anyways?  IMHO a 6-week delay is perfectly fine.

Flexibility of Governance - I'm aware that a new NCL can be passed that is lower.  However, I worry that once we have a high NCL passed, many of the top dReps who happen to have budget proposals will rigorously defend the high limit so that their proposals have a better chance.  Better to approve a low NCL and then raise it later if we have to IMHO.

Market Timing and Investment Windows - I don't think any of the budget proposals mentioned so far move the needle enough in a positive direction to be worth the ADA they are asking for.  What is the PMF we are trying to market?  What strategic initiatives other than ones in IOG's core proposal, Midgard, Starstream, Amaru, and Gerolamo are needed?  All of those combined are still less than 200M ADA.  Also, I support a stablecoin liquidity proposal, but it needs to be decoupled from Emurgo's omnibus proposal IMHO.

Checks and Balances - The issue here is not necessarily that dReps will want to spend up to the cap.  It's that budget proposers will.  We don't have enough visibility into ANY of the proposals' true costs.  Example:  Maybe with a 150M NCL, IOG might propose 50M for their core proposal.  With 350M NCL, there is enough room for them to ask for 100M first just to see if it passes.  We WANT budget proposers to be *LIMITED* by the NCL to get them to compete to lower costs.

Misuse Isnâ€™t Solved by NCL Alone - Agreed.  But IMHO lowering the NCL will cause proposers to increase the *quality* of their proposals in order to compete with other proposers for a slice of a smaller pie.

Selling Pressure and Timing - ADA is currently 5x below ATH.  I very much doubt that it will be on its way back down again 6 weeks from now.  In fact I think if we delay a little bit we'll be more likely to stretch the value of our ADA spent to go much further.

These are some of the main reasons I am strongly against approving a 350M NCL right now.

Proposal: 2025 Net Change Limit

Voting Rationale â€“ 2025 Net Change Limit (NCL)

I'm voting YES on this governance action â€” not because it's perfect, but because having a 350M â‚³ budget is better than having no budget at all for the months ahead. We can't afford a governance deadlock. The ecosystem needs continuity, especially as we step into a new era of on-chain decision-making. 350M â‚³ its still a huge number, I would be more comfortable with spending 250M â‚³ in 2025.

That said, here's some nuance:

This should have been a percentage, not a fixed yearly number. A percentage of treasury inflows keeps us flexible and aligned with network growth. Hard limits age quickly and tie our hands â€” not great for dynamic environments like blockchain governance.

I already voted NO on the 2025 + 2026 NCL combo proposal. Why? Because locking ourselves into 2026 without deeper analysis or flexibility is not a sustainable strategy for a new governance system. Each year should be modeled and discussed based on fresh data and needs â€” not bundled and rushed.

While Iâ€™m voting YES on the 350M â‚³ NCL for 2025, I plan to be disciplined in budget reviews. That means Iâ€™ll most likely supporting withdrawals up to 300M â‚³ as a counterbalance, pushing for fiscal responsibility and impact-driven funding. Budgets tend to expand to its upper limit, that's why I'm doing this counterbalance. Although most likely a symbolic one.

So yes â€” this vote is strategic, not enthusiastic. It's about keeping Cardano moving while holding the line on value, accountability, and progress.

I encourage all Cardano DReps that have not voted yet to go to GovTool and vote â€˜Yesâ€™ on the Info Action that enables the â‚³350M net change limit (NCL) for the Cardano Treasury. 

I am in favor of a â‚³350M net change limit. We need an NCL. Voting on this Info Action is open right now: https://t.co/y2QhpF7s30

Additional thoughts:

- Approving this limit is the shortest path to getting builders funded in the Cardano ecosystem. If we propose an arbitrarily smaller NCL info action, it will need to go through approval and will delay this process by another month. 

- This NCL creates a cap of what we can possibly spend in the coming year. This does not mean we are approving a â‚³350M withdrawal (or any withdrawal at this time) from the Cardano Treasury.

- This Info Action already has 50%+ approval from the DReps, and its approval allows us to start the process of funding projects building on Cardano.

-  This net change limit value is about equivalent to the income of the Cardano Treasury in the past year. From January 5th, 2024, Epoch 459, through December 30th, Epoch 531, the actual total income into the Cardano Treasury was 335,957,093 ada. So this NCL essentially states that we will not spend more than what we made last year. I think thatâ€™s a pretty reasonable statement.

- Just as easily as we are having a vote now, we can vote to revise the NCL in 2026. I would expect that the DReps will vote to adjust the NCL appropriately over time to ensure sustainable deployment of the Cardano Treasury. 

- There is a balance between â€˜spending and being wastefulâ€™ versus â€˜not spending and constraining the ecosystem.â€™ This NCL puts a reasonable guardrail on those discussions.

We need to accept that we will make mistakes, and that's okay â€” because we will address them and learn from them.
Because that's how we get better.

Matthew 25:14â€“30
