I voted NO â›”ï¸to reduce the Net Change Limit (NCL) to 200M ADA, which has been one of the toughest governance decisions so far. 

It feels like thereâ€™s no entirely good option here.

Moreover, I myself called for a lower NCL.

The current NCL of 350M ADA has some notable drawbacks.

If high selling pressure causes ADAâ€™s price to drop significantly, say to 0.2 USD, it could result in serious challenges. 

Funding the ecosystem in dollar terms would require selling a large amount of ADA from the treasury, leading to a spiral of selling pressure that could worsen the situation.

Cardano Whale (@cardano_whale) pointed out that some projects like Tezos and Polkadot have invested heavily in their ecosystems, possess innovative technologies, yet struggle to gain substantial attention.

I fully agree with that.

For blockchains, maintaining a presence in the top 10 market capitalization rankings is vital.

Retail investors, institutions, and crypto enthusiasts evaluate projects not only based on technology but also on market performance. 

If Cardano drops out of the top 10 for an extended period, it may never regain its position, regardless of decentralization or technological progress like Ouroboros Leios. 

This is an important factor to consider, even if it feels unfair or subjective.

On the other hand, reducing the NCL to 200M ADA comes with its own set of concerns.

Cardano needs investments to advance its technology, support builders, and develop the ecosystem. Without increased user activity, Treasury revenue won't grow. 

Spending on maintenance and development in the next years risks exhausting the reserve, ultimately making Cardano economically unsustainable.

Protocol security also hinges on attractive staking rewards and incentives. Moreover, Ouroboros Leiosâ€™s potential will remain untapped without active developers, tools, and a growing DeFi ecosystem. Investments in all these areas are crucial.

IOG has made their funding requirements clear: Core Dev needs 96M ADA, Catalyst 69M ADA, and Research 27M ADA. Combined, this totals 192M ADA. The offer from IOG is simple: either approve this funding or let it be.

Debates around fairness, IOG and Charlesâ€™s past contributions, and the definition of â€œcompletionâ€ for Cardano have their place, but the reality is that IOG holds unmatched expertise in the protocol. No other entity can effectively take over maintenance, development, and research at the same pace or quality.

If DReps allocate 192M ADA to IOG, only 8M ADA remains for other projects.

After reviewing budget proposals, I supported only the essentials I believe the ecosystem absolutely needs: projects like Midgard, Starstream, Hydra, ZK Rollups, Blockfrost, Lucid, Chainlink integration, and others. 

For the CORE category alone, this amounts to around 12M ADA. Across all categories, my total approved budget comes to 213M ADA.

Given my own estimate of required expenditures is 213M ADA, I cannot support an NCL of 200M ADA. 

It would contradict my stance on necessary project funding versus the cap I approve. This inconsistency guided my decision to vote NO on reducing the NCL.

Cardano requires effective marketing and improved governance support, as the current situation is far from ideal.

Investing in the ecosystem and advancing new technologies must go hand in hand to ensure sustainable growth.

Approving the NCL of 200M ADA, in my view, would mean preserving the status quo, leaving all key responsibilities to IOG while neglecting investment in the broader ecosystem. 

Essentially, it would restrict funding for entities that are vital to the ecosystem, just as IOG is.

An important consideration is the expected scenarios surrounding the NCL.

Both NCLs, an NCL of 350M ADA and 200M ADA, are extremes in my view.

The current NCL, set at 350M ADA, has strong support with 76% of the voting stake participating. Nearly the entire voting stake approved it. Drastically reducing the NCL from 350M to 200M ADA would be either irresponsible or overly ambitious.

What would happen next? Builders, Intersect, IOG, or others would likely submit a new governance action proposing an intermediate NCL, perhaps 250M or 300M ADA. Alternatively, multiple proposals could be submitted simultaneously.

This scenario would create an unstable environment that is counterproductive and difficult to support. Such instability undermines progress.

Moreover, the crypto community has little interest in prolonged debates about how much the Cardano ecosystem can afford to invest.

In an unstable environment, even proposing a coherent budget becomes nearly impossible.

Currently, we have an NCL of 350M ADA. Consider this likely scenario:

Intersect is expected to submit a governance action for the budget expiring in June. Meanwhile, if a new NCL of 200M ADA is approved by the end of May, the proposed budget would effectively become unconstitutional unless it is approved before the new NCL takes effect. 

This complicates the process and further highlights the issues with sudden, extreme changes.

Debating the NCL through governance actions is both inefficient and overly time-consuming.

It seems likely that the community's consensus would fall somewhere between 250Mâ€“300M ADA. However, no off-chain temperature check was conducted (to which the majority of the community would respond) before the on-chain vote, which led to the current NCL being approved simply to allow the budgeting process to continue.

The concept of the NCL itself is starting to feel unnecessary, as it constantly shifts based on the majority vote. If the voting stake agrees to increase or decrease the NCL, it will inevitably happen.

Itâ€™s important to emphasize that the NCL doesnâ€™t dictate the amount that must be spent from the treasury. Every withdrawal proposal still requires approval from the community.

I would likely vote YES if the current proposal fell within the 250Mâ€“300M ADA range. If a proposal like this is submitted, I would support it, as it aligns with the budget I consider reasonable based on the proposals I have endorsed.

However, my decision isnâ€™t final and may change depending on future developments in governance. 

For instance, if governance actions combine multiple proposals that result in an excessively high total cost, or if the IOG proposal is grouped with several proposals I donâ€™t support, or one I strongly oppose, such as the Daedalus 2025 Service Enhancement, I might reconsider my stance.

If the only way to prevent a poor budget outcome is to vote for a lower NCL, I am prepared to do so. This decision is nuanced and cannot be seen in black-and-white terms.

I want to avoid a scenario where approving a lower NCL inevitably results in another GA submission. Addressing the NCL repeatedly is time-consuming and unproductive. 

DReps need to prioritize budget proposals instead.

A higher NCL serves no purpose if it ends up funding low-quality projects within the budget.

Itâ€™s time to report on my recent votes! Long read below ðŸ‘‡

Starting with the NCL, I voted in favor of a larger 350m limit. The main reasoning was that a delay in funding could be detrimental for many smaller projects on Cardano. Without the NCL, treasury withdrawals cannot be done, so we needed to set up one. Now that this problem is solved, I am considering whether it makes sense to lower the limit to 200m. Currently, leaning no on this one as I believe we are at a critical moment for the ecosystem and have to spend resources aggressively to catch up in the areas where we are lagging.

Regarding the budget items, my process was as follows. Having limited time, I prioritized a) more expensive items that have a bigger impact on the budget and b) more technical items where I have some expertise. My default was the â€œabstainâ€ option, which I used in situations where I felt I could not offer a good insight on why the proposal should be accepted or rejected. I am obviously biased about @zkFoldâ€™s proposals, but I tried to consider every proposal on its own merit and not how it would benefit us as a company (as you can see below). I also paid a lot of attention to the costs. I believe thereâ€™s (almost?) no irreplaceable vendors, and so thereâ€™s always room for negotiation with regards to outputs and cost. Everything below is my personal opinion as a DRep. Notable items that I voted on:

- @InputOutputHK's research proposal was one of the easiest votes. We should definitely advance in those research items as they provide our ecosystem with an edge over the competition. And the price tag is moderate, all things considered.

- Next, I also voted in favor of the @InputOutputHK's development proposal. Most of the items make total sense to me, although the cost is high. It is a minor thing, but I do hope the Babel fees project is just marketed as such, but is actually a comprehensive solution for partially balanced transactions. Babel fees are being implemented independently by different ecosystem players, including @FluidTokens and @zkFold. They do not require a hardfork, per se. And the budget for this single item (babel fees) is more than @zkFold's yearly budget.

- Then, I voted for @zkFoldâ€™s proposals as well as @AnastasiaLabs's Midgard and @SebastienGllmt's Starstream. I think all these technologies can have a huge impact compared to their price. Yes, there is some overlap between those, but we donâ€™t know how things play out, so making many small bets with 100x potential makes the most sense to me.

- With some hesitation, I voted for the Project Catalyst budget. On the one hand, the roadmap looks really promising. I do like what is written in the proposal. On the other hand, the cost is very high, and the Project Catalyst experience for proposers has been degrading, in my opinion. Given that the Cardano governance has matured since early funds, we can afford to have less bureaucracy and overhead, not more! The ecosystem can now filter bad proposals much more efficiently without Catalystâ€™s team handholding. And when the Catalystâ€™s team mediation is needed, it is lacking. All in all, though, Catalyst has been highly beneficial for the ecosystem.

- I voted â€œnoâ€ on the Tweag proposal as the concerns of other DReps have not been properly cleared, and the TSC review added more on top (300k+ per developer in France, really?).

- I voted â€œnoâ€ on the Intersect proposal. The situation around TSC is concerning, and, in my opinion, it highlights the extreme degree of centralization in the organization. The proposal asks for a huge sum, while the expense items are vague. We are creating committees that cannot make any decisions on their own and serve as very expensive analysts for the board. At least, thatâ€™s how it looks to me. Happy to be corrected.

- Finally, I voted in favor of @TxPipeâ€™s proposals as, in the past, theyâ€™ve produced great products that reduced development costs for numerous Cardano projects. Plus, it is not easy to monetize those tools, so the ecosystem should support them.

tweets.originalText:
Intersect coordinated a 2025 Cardano budget. Nearly 200 proposals were bundled into one to simplify voting and support core operations across the ecosystem.

The process has been messy. There has been confusion, frustration, and legitimate concerns. Still, Intersect pulled this proposal together and put it forward for a vote.

Now people want to vote for the proposals inside but not fund Intersect itself. That leaves the proposals orphaned with an administrator with no funds.
It's like approving the orphanage but abandoning the staff.

Without Intersect, the whole proposal falls apart. Each project will need to resubmit and find a new administrator.

So if you do not want Intersect's version of the Cardano budget, why vote on it at all? If you are not funding the structure, you are not supporting the plan.

I encourage all DReps to vote "YES" to fund @IntersectMBO for 2025-2026. 

Interesect's funding proposal: https://t.co/eNrxNfASyK

---

Additional Notes: 

I am a member of the Intersect's Cardano Budget Committee (@IntersectCBC). I joined in order to build a process for builders, developers, and marketers to apply for and receive funding from the Treasury via DRep approval. Developing this process has been difficult at times, but I believe that Intersect is on the right track, and it is in our interest as a Community to fund and further develop this Institution. At present, this is our best vehicle for involving the broader @Cardano community in on-chain governance.

- (1) Intersect will serve as Administrator for Treasury-funded contracts - All proposals that have received a "YES" vote from the DReps need an Administrator. To my knowledge, no other organization has stepped forward to act as an Administrator for these proposals. Intersect can serve in this vital role. 

- (2) Intersect does not have sole control over Treasury fund disbursement - Intersect will work within a set of multiple key holders to administer the smart contract that releases funds to the teams. They will not unilaterally withhold or release funds. This set of key holders will represent the builders in the Cardano community. 
  
- (3) Processes and performance - We should judge this organization based on its failures but its successes. While imperfect, Intersect has helped pass a Cardano net change limit and has arrived at a Budget Reconciliation process with Ekklesia.  The Cardano Annual Budget process is now working. In 2022-2024, in conjunction with IOG, Intersect successfully coordinated a global conversation around the governance guardrail CIP-1694 and the first Constitution for Cardano. This was also a hugely successful effort. Let's not lose sight of the forest for the trees: Intersect is functioning. 
  
- (4) Leadership and community involvement - Jack Briggs (@JBriggsLondon) is leading the work at Intersect with Nick Cook (@NC_IntersectMBO), and I believe in their leadership. I also personally know many of the team members at Intersect, and I vouch for their efficacy and diligence in their work. These team members are on the ground at events, they are participating online in discussion, and they are accessible to the community. Additionally, we have just seen community members newly elected to all Intersect committees. I believe that these leaders will steer Intersect to an even better state.
  
- (5) Time limit - This funding will be only for one year. If we find that Intersect does not do its job or meaningfully advance the interests of the Cardano community through its efforts, I will not call for support for this organization again.

- (6) Demonstrated willingness to listen and to change - This organization has listened to community feedback and has revised its approach multiple times. It is sensitive to the will of the Cardano community and will continue to iterate until they get things right. In my mind, this is the essence of the Age of Voltaire. Nobody gave us a playbook as a Community, and folks took a chance to work at a new organization and adapt as quickly as possible while enduring intense, deserved scrutiny. I believe this willingness to listen and adapt gives them the mandate to lead.

Love the amazing passive and debate of the DReps.  Shows the beauty of Cardano Community led governance.  Thought it might be helpful to post for everyone what the Cardano Constitution requires:

1. An administrator Is Constitutionally Required--
The Constitution mandates that all Cardano ecosystem budgets must designate one or more administrators to oversee treasury funds. Without Intersect acting as administrator (or the emergence of a different administrator acceptable to DReps) no budget can fulfill this requirement.
â†’ Constitution Reference: Article IV, Section 2

2. No Administrator means no budgetâ€”and No Governance Execution--
Treasury withdrawals cannot occur unless they are part of an approved budget and under the supervision of a designated administrator. Without funding for Intersect (or the emergence of a different administrator acceptable to DReps) there is no administratorâ€”effectively halting the execution of any governance action involving treasury funds.
â†’ Constitution Reference: Article IV, Sections 2 & 3; Guardrails TREASURY-04a

3. Administrators Enable Treasury Withdrawals--
Only an approved budget that includes an administrator allows treasury withdrawals. Intersect (or a different entity acceptable to DReps, acting as the administrator) is thus essential to implement any community-approved funding, ensuring the budget's legitimacy and compliance.
â†’ Constitution Reference: Article IV, Sections 2 & 3; Guardrails TREASURY-01a to TREASURY-04a

4. Intersect (or  a different entity acceptable to DReps) acting as the administrator, ensures Budget Oversight, Transparency, and Audits--
The Constitution requires that all treasury withdrawals include allocations for independent audits and oversight metrics. Intersect (or  a different entity acceptable to DReps, acting as the administrator) fulfills this role by managing separate, auditable accounts and implementing governance-related dispute resolution.
â†’ Constitution Reference: Article IV, Section 4 & 5

5. Intersect (or a different entity acceptable to DReps, acting as the administrator) sustains Governance Infrastructure--
The Constitution expects the community to maintain off-chain governance processes. Intersect, as an MBO, supports essential infrastructure including tooling, process administration, and the Constitutional Committeeâ€™s operational needs. Another entity would have to step up to take on this role if Intersect ceases to exist.
â†’ Constitution Reference: Article III, Section 6; Article VII, Sections 7 & 8

6. No Administrator Risks the Entire Governance Model-
Intersectâ€™s (or a different  administrator's) administrative function is foundational and mandatory to Cardanoâ€™s governance. Without a funded administrator, no treasury-based governance actions can proceed, undermining DRepsâ€™ decisions and threatening the continuity of decentralized governance.
â†’ Constitution Reference: Article IV, Sections 2â€“5; Article VII, Section 4

tweets.originalText: DReps have the absolute right to reject Intersect's budget proposal.  That's amazing democracy in action!  What would happen next is that one or more alternative administrators would have to emerge and get funding.  All previously approved budgets that had designated Intersect as their administrator would have to be resubmitted and new votes would have to take place.  The new administrator or administrators identified in resubmitted budget proposals would have to also separately submit their own budget proposals for funding.  Going this direction is the right of the Cardano Community.  Of course it would likely result in a delay of any treasury withdrawals by at least 3 to 6 months, potentially creating a risk for the ongoing operation of Cardano.  Again, however, this is for the Cardano community to decide.  Challenging problems indeed but so wonderful to see our DReps engaging in such important debates and considerations.

As many of us expected, the NCL thus becomes the target and Intersect just put a gargantuan 275m ADA budget info action on-chain. I voted against.

I have repeatedly explained - presumably on behalf of a few more people than just my little old self - not to play it like this. Here we see a budget request bucketing what I consider critical tech work with what in my mind at least have the potential to be downright scams.

We see ourselves in the position where we are forced to accept ~125m of, at best, nice to have spending that the on-chain spam filters likely would have stopped in its tracks, along with ~150m of critical tech work. Work that itself in some cases comes with such a hefty price tag that the on-chain governance process and DRep set should be allowed to directly engage with it before approving. 

In prior votes I have at length explained why we cannot be too excessive with treasury disbursements. High level: 

Weâ€™re tinkering with monetary policy, it is a mistake to view the treasury through a fiscal or even budgetary lens. 

Crypto is about disinflation, Bitcoin is sub 1% now (putting everyone under pressure, 2025 is not 2020) while Cardano is sub 2%. Treasury spending introduces new inflation at a time other protocols like BNB and Tron have manually had to burn double digits of supply to stay around the top 10. 

If this spending comes along with adoption or big imminent improvements to Cardano it may be worth it, but it canâ€™t be haphazard and it makes sense to start cautiously. I consider this Intersect budget proposal to be haphazard, and want to flag my discontent with the entire process. 

Voting should have been done on-chain from day 1, scrutinised by the full DRep set and with appropriate spam filters applied. Maybe at most bucketing several smaller cost effective and highly related proposals like we saw with Midgard and Starstream.

But also, even if we were to see this exercise as a sort of fiscal budgeting, budgeting is not about finding out how many items have a critical mass of people who would like to spend on them. Itâ€™s about combining those preferences with a set of considerations that include first understanding how much we CAN spend first, and then being SELECTIVE about it. 

The worry I and many others have had, that the NCL becomes the target instead of a constraint, is now turning out to be valid. I donâ€™t think the market in 2025-26 has the appetite to stomach 350m ADA in emissions, or even 275m. 

I have lodged complaints about the process here before and have signalled multiple times I would not be able to support such a budget. I will once again reiterate that this spending path we are on is the single biggest risk to Cardano currently. I worry.

ðŸš«I voted NO on the Cardano Blockchain Ecosystem Budget of 275M ADA, administered by Intersect.

Rationale:

I strongly oppose bundling all proposals into a single bundle for DReps to approve.

Critical proposals are grouped with less important or unnecessary ones, many of which belong to Catalyst.

Budget responsibility requires making decisions on individual proposals or smaller bundles, not one large one.

Proposal Breakdown:

â€¢ In Ekklesia, I voted YES for 35 proposals totaling 213.3M ADAâ€”which is 62M ADA lower than the collective DRep-approved budget in Ekklesia.

â€¢ A separate GA exists for six of the proposals I supportedâ€”these are top-tier projects that most DReps agree will positively impact the ecosystem.

â€¢ Intersectâ€™s GA includes 19 proposals I want to support, totaling 204.2M ADA, including four IOG projects with a combined budget of 194M ADA.

â€¢ At the same time, 14 proposals totaling 65.5M ADA were proposals I did not support in Ekklesia.

Assuming that IOG is able to submit its own GA for their proposals, I am talking about supporting 15 proposals with a total budget of 10M ADA that I want to support. 

Against this are 14 proposals with a budget of 65.5M ADA that I do not want to support.

As a DRep, I cannot accept it.

In my case, this imbalance makes the bundled approach unacceptable. I believe that many DReps will struggle with this as well.

Preferred Alternative:

I urge teams to submit their own GAs or ask Intersect to structure proposals by category or threshold.

â€¢ On-chain voting for individual proposals would be ideal, though the 100K ADA deposit for GA submissions is a challenge for many projects.

â€¢ Smaller, more focused GA bundles would allow better decision-making.

Net Change Limit (NCL) Concerns:

The current NCL is unclear, making a 275M ADA budget approval premature. There are two active GAs regarding NCL:

1. 200M ADA NCL that expires May 29, 2025.
2. 300M ADA NCL that expires June 8, 2025.

The existing NCL received strong support, but many DReps may have backed it simply to keep the budget process moving, not because they favored a high limit.

Until DReps align on the NCL, approving such a large budget makes little sense.

This GA expires June 13, 2025. If both active NCL GAs fail, confirming the current NCL, I will still have one epoch to reconsider my vote.

Next Steps & My Position:

I urge DReps to vote on the NCL GAs as soon as possible.

I continue to believe that budgetary responsibility is best maintained by voting on individual proposals rather than relying on an NCL. Letâ€™s handle this on-chain.

My NO vote is a signal to Intersect that I support a process change. I do not want to approve one large bundle worth 275M ADAâ€”I prefer individual votes or smaller proposal bundles.

However, my support for the projects I voted YES in Ekklesia remains firm. I will vote YES if they submit their own GA.

I am also open to reconsidering all proposals, as long as they come through proper GA submissions.

Ultimately, I believe the ideal NCL should be around 250M ADA, with 10M ADA kept as a reserve for emergencies.

Balancing monetary policy protection and ecosystem investment is a challengeâ€”we must minimize selling pressure while funding growth.

The solution is ensuring that only projects with a positive long-term impact receive ADA from the Treasury.

In my view, some proposals in the current bundle are unnecessary.

My DRep ID:

VOTE âŒ: Cardano Blockchain Ecosystem Budget - 275M ada Administered by Intersect 

===================
Please redelegate to another DRep, if you disagree with my NO vote. If you redelegate to a YES voting DRep, it will count as a YES. 
===================

RATIONALE
I am voting NO on the proposed 2025 Cardano Blockchain Ecosystem Budget because I believe the total amount requested is too high, especially  for the first year of minimum viable on-chain governance. 

I also believe that bundling 39 proposals together into a single vote limits DRepsâ€™ ability to express the differentiated support that we saw in earlier stages. This approach flattens nuance and imposes an all-or-nothing decision on a diverse set of funding priorities.

I also acknowledge the existence of the three founding entities that were allocated Genesis ADA that are working with different levels of success to improve Cardano according to their original missions. Some of these missions have been nominally completed, some of these missions continue in their original form, some continue in a new form. I do not pretend to know all the nuances. 

Still I take that as a factor in my decision-making. Treasury funds should be used judiciously in complement and in awareness of the existence of the entities. 

This vote against this Budget in its full size is based on:

1. My participation in the DRep voting stage and the level of DRep participation as a whole;
2. The level of support that some proposals received relative to others;
3. The relative importance of certain proposals vs others and the quality of the teams and their dedication to Cardanoâ€™s mission;
4. And the expectation that Catalyst will likely gain sufficient support (in this or future budget proposals) to continue to support smaller, experimental, or commercial projects.

While spending from the Treasury is not new (Catalyst has done it before), this is the first major annual on-chain budget, and it sets a precedent.

In my view, the issue is not inflation within the Cardano economy â€” most ADA will not be used to buy NFTs or FTs. Nor is it simply about a slightly higher disinflation rate. The deeper issue is ADA devaluation due to external sell pressure. Most of the funded ADA will be exchanged for fiat (USD, EUR, etc.), not recycled internally. This adds downward pressure on ADAâ€™s price.

It is a see-saw that has its quirks. 

In a real-world economy, if you spend more to "jumpstart" the economy, face inflation if the supply of services and goods cannot meet demand. 

In a still nascent blockchain economy, spending more essentially means converting the native token for fiat, and the result is devaluation. We are not exchanging ADA directly for Cardano economy goods and services, we are selling it into the real world. The ADA is not recycled internally. This adds downward pressure on ADAâ€™s price.

This devaluation affects everyone:

1. The most important funded projects
2. The projects that were not funded
3. The builders who didnâ€™t ask for funding 
4. The ADA holders who fund all of it through opportunity cost

Of course, that is unavoidable. Most of the ADA allocated will likely be converted to fiat (USD, EUR, etc.) to pay for services, not retained or reused within the ecosystem. This creates exchange rate pressure, weakening ADAâ€™s value.

The question isnâ€™t whether devaluation will occur â€” it will. The real question is: Where do we draw the line? Do all 39 proposals in this budget bring more value than the cost of the devaluation they collectively impose? Do we need to bundle them all in one YES/NO budget vote? I think No. 

We are approving a large, externally-focused budget at a time when Cardanoâ€™s â€œblockchain economyâ€ and governance mechanism is still immature and internally fragile.

Treasury funds should primarily be focused on critical public goods in different forms. Especially if they are open source; support infrastructure, research, tools, even education, promotion of Cardano. This applies when the goods align with the long-term mission of Cardano as public infrastructure. Yes, there may be exceptions that emerge, but those exceptions are expensive â€” and others will pay for them.

If we overfund less impactful proposals, we risk undermining the impact of the most critical ones, simply by diluting the value of what they are paid in.

For this reason, I believe a smaller, phased budget focused tightly on foundational public goods would be a better and safer starting point.

I include this rationale as an earnest view of the proposed budget action with the aim of contributing to the process by encouraging the submitter (Intersect) to take more factors into account.

meta.title: 2025 Cardano Blockchain Ecosystem Budget - 7.5M â‚³ for community builders
meta.abstract:
The Cardano 2025 on-chain budget process introduces a constitutionally driven, community-led model for treasury allocation. ADA holders, through Delegated Representatives (DReps) and Constitutional Committee oversight, vote on funding proposals within a capped Net Change Limit of 350 million ADA. The process includes two stages: community signaling and a binding on-chain Info Action vote.
Intersect, a member-based organization, facilitates the process by organizing submissions and offering domain expertise, while final decisions rest with the community. Intersect also serves as the administrator for the use of approved funds.
Current metrics show 11.22B ADA delegated, with 3.92B cast in Ekklesiaâ€”72% participation of active voting power. Yet, several proposals advanced without meeting a basic 50 + 1 Lovelace% threshold (2.69B ADA), raising concerns about legitimacy and governance integrity.
This info action aim to help community builders to quickly get approval onchain while individually they might not have 100k ADA deposit readily available. We submit all proposals (except founding entity proposals) that have met the 2.69B threshold for inclusion. Without respecting the safeguards put in place within the Cardano Constitution, low-support proposals may continue to pass, risking public confidence within the entire budgetary process. 
The 2025 budget process reflects Cardanoâ€™s Voltaire visionâ€”but its long-term success depends on transparency and accountability aligned with the constitution.
meta.rationale:
The 2025 Cardano budget process is built to reconcile strategic planning with decentralized authority, ensuring that treasury allocations are community-driven, constitutionally sound, and economically sustainable. It emphasizes transparency, voting legitimacy, and fiscal restraintâ€”all within the framework of the Cardano Constitution and Net Change Limit (NCL).

---

### 1. Proposal Submission & Consolidation

The process began with dual intake:

- **Block Budgets** from Intersectâ€™s seven working committees (technical, governance, marketing, etc.)
- **Open Submissions** from any Cardano contributor, regardless of Intersect membership.

All submissions were standardizedâ€”detailing problem, benefit, roadmap alignment, and costâ€”to ensure fair and structured evaluation. Founding entities (Intersect, IOG, Cardano Foundation, Emurgo) were expected to submit **independent Info Actions** and were **not bundled** with the general budget. An off-chain signaling phase enabled DReps and ADA holders to express preliminary support via GovTool and Ekklesia. Proposals that passed community signaling with >2.69B ADA were packaged into this *Budget Info Action* for on-chain ratification. In accordance with **Article IV of the Cardano Constitution**, a valid budget requires:

- A **DRep vote surpassing 50%+1 Lovelace of active voting power** (â‰¥2.69B ADA)
- A **minimum of 5 out of 7 Constitutional Committee votes** affirming that the budget complies with the Constitution
- All treasury disbursements to remain **within the 2025 Net Change Limit** (350 million ADA)

---

This *Budget Info Action* complies with all of the above. DReps now vote knowing that **only proposals that passed the threshold and are constitutionally sound are included**.

What's at stake for the future of Cardano: The Update, The Constitution, the Treasury, and the Budgets.

The Plomin Hard Fork 

This update will be the final step to full participation in Cardano Governance as designed by CIP-1694. Expect to see the Plomin Hard Fork submitted on chain very soon.  A few months ago, when the Chang Hard Fork was enacted, it activated the Governance Bootstrap Phase which allowed Delegated Representatives (DReps) to register on-chain and established the Constitutional Committee (CC) to vote on Governance Actions (GAs) along with Stake Pool Operators (SPOs).  However, governance was limited.

Once the Plomin Hard Fork passes the DReps will gain full voting power, not just the ability to vote on Info Actions (visit https://t.co/aRWErA7Waj for a guide to the different type of Governance Actions).  This means that the Cardano Community will be able to update the Cardano Constitution and withdraw funds from the Cardano Treasury.

Why do we care about establishing the Constitution and withdrawing funds from the Treasury?  Well, quite frankly, it's because Cardano has grown up and we have to start living on our own now.  When Cardano was launched in 2017 the pioneering entities were given grants of Ada (about 20% of the total supply) in order to deliver us a decentralized ecosystem that the we, the users, could govern ourselves.  Now that we have the power of governance we need to firmly set the ground rules that protects the rights of everyone who interacts in the Cardano ecosystem, we need to collectively decide on the future development roadmap of Cardano, and we need to have a way to pay for it!

The Constitution

The past few months have been a historic time for Cardano as the community engaged in a deliberative process to draft a new Constitution.  While an Interim Constitution had been established with the Chang Hard Fork that document was written with an intentional plan for replacement.  @IntersectMBO with the help of @InputOutputHK, @Cardano_CF, @emurgo_io, and countless community contributors held 63 workshops across the world where Delegates for a Constitutional Convention were selected. These Delegates participated in synthesis sessions to review the language of the proposed new constitution that had been drafted by the Cardano Civics Committee of Intersect, solicited community feedback on proposed changes, and then came together in Buenos Aires and Nairobi to debate and approve a final draft.

All that being said, this new Constitution is not yet approved!  In a decentralized ecosystem of blockchain technology like Cardano, the establishment of a new Constitution cannot be valid until the Ada holders, as represented by their DReps, vote in favor.  Once the Plomin Hard Fork has passed (fingers crossed!) the community will be able to consider a Governance Action to ratify the new Constitution.  We can continue to operate under the Interim Constitution, if we must, but it would be far preferable to move to a new Constitution that came from a community review process as soon as possible.

The Treasury

One of the most unique and powerful aspects of Cardano is that we have a common Treasury to provide for the operation, maintenance, and future development of the blockchain ecosystem. Each Epoch, 20% of the Rewards Pool (transaction fees and monetary expansion) goes to the Treasury instead while the rest goes to Staking Rewards.

Because this Treasury comes out of the Staking Rewards that would otherwise go to the members of the Cardano Community, it is essential that the fund be safeguarded.  That is why the Interim Constitution and the proposed Constitution both specify that a Net Change Limit must be approved through a Governance Info Action before any Treasury Withdrawals are made.

The Net Change Limit that is adopted by the community must define how much Ada can be spent out of the Treasury in a certain amount of time.  For practical purposes (at least as we start), this will most likely mean that we decide how much to spend in 73 epochs (a calendar year).  Because the CC is obligated to vote down any Treasury Withdrawal GA that does not fit within the established Net Change Limit, we must make sure that this value fits within our planned spending for the year and allows for contingencies that may come up.  There is a fine balance to be struck!

The Budgets

In addition to the Net Change Limit, the Interim Constitution and the proposed Constitution specify that the no Treasury Withdrawal GA can pass unless it fits within a Budget that has been approved by the Cardano community through a vote by DReps.  The CC must also vote on any proposed budget to ensure that proposed spending does not violate the Constitution.

With text of the Constitution, the Budget requirements are purposefully flexible to give the Cardano Community options to fund the decentralized ecosystem.  While the Interim Constitution simply says there must be some Budget in place, the proposed Constitution is a bit more explicit in describing how each Budget must have an Administrator to ensure Treasury Withdrawals are properly spent.  This Administrator could be a person, an institution, or a smart contract, and I expect we will see this practice evolve over time.

While anyone on Cardano can propose a budget, a large amount of community effort has been focused on working with @IntersectMBO to propose a comprehensive budget to support Cardano in 2025.  This process is nearing completion and the Budget Committee has stated they will be ready to report their proposal to the community soon.  They have already held numerous community meetings describing the process and soliciting feedback.

One of the keys to Intersect's approach will be to ensure that there is no single person in charge of the administration of funds.  The Budgets that Intersect will propose will give Administrator responsibilities to various committees of Intersect that are run by Cardano community members.  Again, we are seeking to balance the benefits of decentralization with the recognition that empowering people to act for the greater good is the best way to move a process forward.

The Timeline & Conclusion

Now that we have a clear picture on what needs to happen for Cardano to move forward, we can discuss the timing of each action. Each time a Governance Action is proposed the Cardano community has 6 Epochs (30 days) to vote on it and then it takes one Epoch for the GA to take effect.  While most actions can pass early (if they get the necessary threshold of Yes votes) it is best to make a conservative estimate that the vote will run the full length of time possible.

If the Plomin Hard Fork GA is submitted on December 21 (the beginning of Cardano Epoch 529) we are looking at probable enactment on January 24 (Epoch 536).  Then, and only then, can we reasonably submit the Constitution for ratification.  The Treasury will also be unlocked and DReps can consider Treasury Withdrawal Governance Actions.

While the Treasury will be unlocked on January 24, provided that the Plomin Hard Fork GA passes, the CC will not approve any actions the DReps take to withdraw funds unless the Net Change Limit and at least one Budget have been approved.  That means that we will need to have the DReps and CC vote on Governance Info Actions to approve these items before any Treasury Withdrawals are submitted.

Fortunately, because DReps are able to vote for Info Actions right now, we do not need to wait for the Plomin Hard Fork to be enacted to begin these discussions.  The community can consider and vote on the Hard Fork, the Net Change Limit, and the proposed Budgets within the same window of time.  We have a lot of important issues to figure out but I am confident that we can work through them and show how decentralized governance can make a Top-10 Blockchain ecosystem not just function but thrive!

If you're a Blockchain Governance nerd like me, you've probably been nodding along as you read this and have been along for the ride up to this point.  If you're just getting into it and have read this far, I hope you'll join us for the next big step of the journey.  Either way, get some rest over the holidays, because January is going to be an exciting time for Cardano!

Maybe rather than tweeting about treasury spending at a high level, I can clarify what some of the spending is that I would actually vote YES for on-chain currently (ie not via off-chain processes, which Iâ€™m not a fan of), if asked to do so.

As always, please delegate to someone else if my approach is not in line with yours:

NCL
A reasonable NCL would in my mind ideally be below 150m, but to be pragmatic Iâ€™m willing to sign off on <= 200m. My reasons for this are well documented, but primarily relate to the emissions-price pressure-value add relationships.

Core dev
A reasonable proposal by IOG to keep delivering on critical roadmap items would get my instant support. In my view the one we have seen on gov tools ticks that box, if with a slightly hefty ask. Also assuming no surprises, Iâ€™d approve associated forks and changes. 

I am aware others besides IOG could do some of the work, but I think a safe approach in the first years of governance would be to only gradually diversify the work beyond IOG, rather than pull away from them immediately. Again, being conservative.

High impact cost efficient proposals
Cost efficient, high impact technology efforts by other, ideally proven, actors. Think Midgard, Starstream or alternative nodes for single digit millions of ADA. Willing to entertain all similar impact and cost efficient ones.

Orgs
Assorted spending for Intersect and similar orgs pushing Cardano forward, if the asks are reasonable and well documented / detailed. Smaller asks will naturally be an easier yes.

Catalyst and/or Intersect budget
A slimmed down version of Catalyst to capture a lot of the efforts others want to put forward. Catalyst is a system that is not perfect, but is improving (eg quadratic voting) and is the current best framework we have for such things. Intersect might complement this, but needs to prove itself.

Summary
This covers core tech, non core tech innovation, orgs and all the other proposals via Intersect/Catalyst.

I think at a high level it should in principle be possible to fit all the above into a NCL of 150m ADA, though that would require some frugality on the part of all participants.

My stance on governance is that it should be transparent and on-chain wherever possible. I am currently unsure whether the Intersect budget process is as robust as what we have in place with Catalyst, and in any case it would need to prove itself.

Therefore my preference would be to pull some of the tech related ones that I mentioned out of this process, and put them to a direct DRep vote fairly soon. Shrink down both Catalyst/Intersect budgets significantly and put them to a vote. Iâ€™ll likely support them.

On the Net Change Limit and Budget Proposals

As a DRep, I cast a YES vote to approve both governance actions (GA) concerning the Net Change Limit (NCL).

At this stage, it appears the second GA will be ratified, setting the NCL at 350M ADA.

Based on feedback from my poll, a substantial portion of the community views this figure as excessive. 

Some DReps are now switching their original YES vote to NO.

In the ongoing poll on whether to approve the second GA regarding NCL or not, the result is half and half.

I will maintain my YES stance, and Iâ€™ll outline why.

We are nearing the end of April, yet an approved NCL is still pending. The ecosystem urgently needs capital allocation to fund development initiatives. Delaying further to wait for another GA cycle would be counterproductive.

Itâ€™s important to consider that many DReps tend to vote in the final stages, and GA ratification typically takes around six epochs (approximately one month). 

If this proposal is ratified, disbursement from the Treasury could begin in May or June. Hopefully!

Yes, a high NCL carries riskâ€”it increases the likelihood of aggressive Treasury drawdowns.

Itâ€™s also worth emphasizing that DReps have the authority to approve spending far below the defined NCL. 

Some voices in the community warn that total expenditures might approach NCL, as if this were a guaranteed outcome. To me, that sounds like a doomsday scenario rather than a realistic forecast. 

The responsibility ultimately lies with the DReps. If each funding decision is evaluated on its individual merits, such overspending canâ€”and shouldâ€”be avoided.

I would support a new GA that proposes a lower NCL, somewhere between 200M and 250M ADA. I would likely vote YES for that.

I am aware of the risk that a few big DReps, including one founding entity, have a very strong position and may refuse to approve a lower NCL.

I am currently reviewing Budget Proposals and have identified around 20 of them that I am inclined to support.

Initially, I assumed that 150M ADA would suffice as my personal NCL threshold. 

However, IOGâ€™s request for ~97M ADA and Catalystâ€™s request for ~70M ADA compel me to raise that estimate. 

I prefer not to set a fixed limit yet, as new proposals continue to surface. Still, I aim to support an overall NCL below 250M ADA. 

I really hope I manage to keep it around 200M ADA.

My preference continues to lean strongly toward Catalyst over Budget Proposals.

Why? 

Because most DReps have indicated a willingness to dedicate just one day per month to governance. 

At present, there are 150 proposals requesting a total of 480M ADA. 

It is dangerous to rely on decision-making by individuals who may spend just a few minutes per proposal. Some proposals may be overlooked entirely. Thatâ€™s irresponsible.

My strategy remains unchanged: I will back only a few essential Budget Proposals alongside Catalyst. 

Most projects should seek funding through Catalyst.

Catalyst offers several clear advantages:

â€¢ A framework that has matured over the years.

â€¢ Teams are familiar with their processes.

â€¢ Funding caps per round introduce a level of fiscal discipline.

â€¢ DReps can participate in community reviews and guide ADA holders on how to vote.

By contrast, the Budget Proposals system is completely untested, and the team behind it remains largely unknown. 

Moreover, Intersect requires a high operational cost.

It makes little sense to allocate hundreds of millions of ADA to a system that hasn't been proven.

This mechanism should be tested first, with limited funds. If successful, it could then be entrusted with a larger portion of Treasury resources.

Interestingly, my poll shows that while there is a preference for Budget Proposals, support for Catalyst remains. 

Some respondents distrust both mechanisms.

I monitor governance developments daily and will adapt as needed. 

If I ultimately decide to change my NCL vote to NO, Iâ€™ll communicate that promptly. As of now, I have no such intention.

Thank you all for the feedback.

I appreciate the transparency. I have a few follow-up questions:

1. Why was the decision made to only count the participating stake when calculating the approval threshold? Thereby deviating from the on-chain governance process.
2. What happens if the approved proposals exceed the NCL?
3. Will there only be two budget info actions submitted by Intersect?
4. When will the budget info actions be submitted?
5. Why is the first reconciliation Workshop 1 day longer?

In my opinion, the decision to count only participating stake, meaning only counting the voting power of DReps that vote yes or no, is too low of a threshold, especially since the voting phase is only two days.

There is a reason why non-participating stake behaves like a NO vote for all governance actions.

IMHO only including participating stake and having a short voting window will make it too easy to be included. 

Some proposals will only be submitted tomorrow (April 24th), so there is not enough time to review them.

TL;DR only considering participating stake with such a short voting period is a mistake that will decrease the legitimacy of the budget info actions

My Rationale for Budget Proposals

I supported 23 projects totaling 222.2M ADA. I voted NO for all others.

Number of supported projects across categories:

â€¢ Core: 17
â€¢ Research: 2
â€¢ Marketing & Innovation: 2
â€¢ Governance support: 2

The 3 largest projects I supported are IOG Core development, IO Research, and Catalyst. 

These 3 items account for 193M ADA.

I was hesitant to support IOG research. In the past, many academic papers have been published. We do not need all the research items on the list for next year. Now it is necessary to support implementation and the ecosystem more, which, in my opinion, is lagging behind research.

On the other hand, Cardano's success is largely based on research and quality implementation using formal methods. 

Not supporting research would be a step aside. Some of the things on the list may be implemented in the future.

My recommendation for next time is to create a separate proposal for each item instead of one proposal with many items. This also applies to Core development.

As I mentioned before, I consider Catalyst to be the place where most projects should apply for funding. That is why I support it.

During the review of Budget Proposals, I noticed that in many cases, only about 2-3 DReps voted. In the best case, about 10, rarely around 20. This is a very low participation.

Catalyst is not perfect, but it has been improved for several years, the team is experienced, and it is a battle-tested tool. ADA holders are already familiar with the system. Moreover, further improvements are planned.

At this point, I see no reason to replace Catalyst with Budget Proposals.

My other recommendation is that IOG should submit separate GAs for their proposals once the NCL is approved. This will avoid the situation where DReps vote on a GA with many other items in one GA.

I only used 29M ADA to support the other 23 projects. 

These are projects that, in my opinion, the ecosystem desperately needs.

I consider Midgard, Starstream, Hydra, ZK Rollups, an alternative Cardano node, integration with Bitcoin, and several others to be must-have projects.

If I came across multiple similar proposals, I preferred open-source projects and entities that are well-known to the community or have delivered a project that is still in use today.

I would like to emphasize that if I voted NO, it could mean:

â€¢ I don't like the project. It shouldn't be funded from Treasury (or Catalyst).

â€¢ I like the project, and it should apply for funding from Catalyst.

In general, I think that projects with ambitions to be commercially successful should look for other sources of funding. 

I don't like it when a risky business is funded from the Treasury, and in case of success, the profit is privatized.

If projects apply for Treasury funding, they should have a strategy on how to return part of the profit back to the community in case of success.

Furthermore, I think that if it is a startup, the team cannot expect that devs will be paid the same salaries as IOG devs. Part of the risk must be borne by the team, not just Treasury.

Some projects do not have a commercial character, for example, libraries, dev tools, etc. We should identify these projects, evaluate their benefits, and possibly support them.

The last major project I supported was the Marketing Strategy from the Cardano Foundation. This also includes the Cardano Summit.

In general, I do not want to support projects from founding entities that hold Genesis coins and have not spent them yet. The Cardano Foundation is such an entity, which was negatively reflected in the last Catalyst Fund.

On the other hand, this proposal was the best in the marketing category. The Cardano Foundation supports many activities in the ecosystem. CF wants to remain active in the long term and support building the ecosystem, for which it needs to secure funding.

The costs of the Cardano Summit and other marketing activities can be high. I would not like to risk that if their proposal is not approved, the next Cardano Summit will not be organized. The crypto industry could perceive this negatively.

I have only supported a single proposal from Intersect regarding the budget for open-source development. They are asking for 5.8M ADA.

New proposals appear every day, so my decision may not be final.  I may make changes.

I voted NO â›”ï¸to reduce the Net Change Limit (NCL) to 200M ADA, which has been one of the toughest governance decisions so far. 

It feels like thereâ€™s no entirely good option here.

Moreover, I myself called for a lower NCL.

The current NCL of 350M ADA has some notable drawbacks.

If high selling pressure causes ADAâ€™s price to drop significantly, say to 0.2 USD, it could result in serious challenges. 

Funding the ecosystem in dollar terms would require selling a large amount of ADA from the treasury, leading to a spiral of selling pressure that could worsen the situation.

Cardano Whale (@cardano_whale) pointed out that some projects like Tezos and Polkadot have invested heavily in their ecosystems, possess innovative technologies, yet struggle to gain substantial attention.

I fully agree with that.

For blockchains, maintaining a presence in the top 10 market capitalization rankings is vital.

Retail investors, institutions, and crypto enthusiasts evaluate projects not only based on technology but also on market performance. 

If Cardano drops out of the top 10 for an extended period, it may never regain its position, regardless of decentralization or technological progress like Ouroboros Leios. 

This is an important factor to consider, even if it feels unfair or subjective.

On the other hand, reducing the NCL to 200M ADA comes with its own set of concerns.

Cardano needs investments to advance its technology, support builders, and develop the ecosystem. Without increased user activity, Treasury revenue won't grow. 

Spending on maintenance and development in the next years risks exhausting the reserve, ultimately making Cardano economically unsustainable.

Protocol security also hinges on attractive staking rewards and incentives. Moreover, Ouroboros Leiosâ€™s potential will remain untapped without active developers, tools, and a growing DeFi ecosystem. Investments in all these areas are crucial.

IOG has made their funding requirements clear: Core Dev needs 96M ADA, Catalyst 69M ADA, and Research 27M ADA. Combined, this totals 192M ADA. The offer from IOG is simple: either approve this funding or let it be.

Debates around fairness, IOG and Charlesâ€™s past contributions, and the definition of â€œcompletionâ€ for Cardano have their place, but the reality is that IOG holds unmatched expertise in the protocol. No other entity can effectively take over maintenance, development, and research at the same pace or quality.

If DReps allocate 192M ADA to IOG, only 8M ADA remains for other projects.

After reviewing budget proposals, I supported only the essentials I believe the ecosystem absolutely needs: projects like Midgard, Starstream, Hydra, ZK Rollups, Blockfrost, Lucid, Chainlink integration, and others. 

For the CORE category alone, this amounts to around 12M ADA. Across all categories, my total approved budget comes to 213M ADA.

Given my own estimate of required expenditures is 213M ADA, I cannot support an NCL of 200M ADA. 

It would contradict my stance on necessary project funding versus the cap I approve. This inconsistency guided my decision to vote NO on reducing the NCL.

Cardano requires effective marketing and improved governance support, as the current situation is far from ideal.

Investing in the ecosystem and advancing new technologies must go hand in hand to ensure sustainable growth.

Approving the NCL of 200M ADA, in my view, would mean preserving the status quo, leaving all key responsibilities to IOG while neglecting investment in the broader ecosystem. 

Essentially, it would restrict funding for entities that are vital to the ecosystem, just as IOG is.

An important consideration is the expected scenarios surrounding the NCL.

Both NCLs, an NCL of 350M ADA and 200M ADA, are extremes in my view.

The current NCL, set at 350M ADA, has strong support with 76% of the voting stake participating. Nearly the entire voting stake approved it. Drastically reducing the NCL from 350M to 200M ADA would be either irresponsible or overly ambitious.

What would happen next? Builders, Intersect, IOG, or others would likely submit a new governance action proposing an intermediate NCL, perhaps 250M or 300M ADA. Alternatively, multiple proposals could be submitted simultaneously.

This scenario would create an unstable environment that is counterproductive and difficult to support. Such instability undermines progress.

Moreover, the crypto community has little interest in prolonged debates about how much the Cardano ecosystem can afford to invest.

In an unstable environment, even proposing a coherent budget becomes nearly impossible.

Currently, we have an NCL of 350M ADA. Consider this likely scenario:

Intersect is expected to submit a governance action for the budget expiring in June. Meanwhile, if a new NCL of 200M ADA is approved by the end of May, the proposed budget would effectively become unconstitutional unless it is approved before the new NCL takes effect. 

This complicates the process and further highlights the issues with sudden, extreme changes.

Debating the NCL through governance actions is both inefficient and overly time-consuming.

It seems likely that the community's consensus would fall somewhere between 250Mâ€“300M ADA. However, no off-chain temperature check was conducted (to which the majority of the community would respond) before the on-chain vote, which led to the current NCL being approved simply to allow the budgeting process to continue.

The concept of the NCL itself is starting to feel unnecessary, as it constantly shifts based on the majority vote. If the voting stake agrees to increase or decrease the NCL, it will inevitably happen.

Itâ€™s important to emphasize that the NCL doesnâ€™t dictate the amount that must be spent from the treasury. Every withdrawal proposal still requires approval from the community.

I would likely vote YES if the current proposal fell within the 250Mâ€“300M ADA range. If a proposal like this is submitted, I would support it, as it aligns with the budget I consider reasonable based on the proposals I have endorsed.

However, my decision isnâ€™t final and may change depending on future developments in governance. 

For instance, if governance actions combine multiple proposals that result in an excessively high total cost, or if the IOG proposal is grouped with several proposals I donâ€™t support, or one I strongly oppose, such as the Daedalus 2025 Service Enhancement, I might reconsider my stance.

If the only way to prevent a poor budget outcome is to vote for a lower NCL, I am prepared to do so. This decision is nuanced and cannot be seen in black-and-white terms.

I want to avoid a scenario where approving a lower NCL inevitably results in another GA submission. Addressing the NCL repeatedly is time-consuming and unproductive. 

DReps need to prioritize budget proposals instead.

A higher NCL serves no purpose if it ends up funding low-quality projects within the budget.

The proposals currently submitted by IOG â€” covering Core Development, Catalyst, and Research â€” already request a total of 193M ADA. Setting the NCL at 200M ADA would nearly exhaust the limit, leaving little room for funding other critical infrastructure proposals. This situation risks hindering Cardanoâ€™s growth.

Fundamentally, the NCL is not a budget intended to be fully spent, but rather a guardrail that defines the maximum amount that may be withdrawn within a given period. As we are still in the early stages of transitioning to on-chain governance, imposing a restrictive cap at this time could undermine the flexibility needed for effective decision-making and timely response.

Moreover, the NCL is not fixed permanently once established. It should be subject to review and adjustment as budget execution progresses and as market conditions evolve.

In this transitional period, it is prudent to design with sufficient margin to accommodate uncertainty. Doing so will support sustainable and strategic ecosystem governance.

ðŸ§­ã€Summary of Adoption Trendsã€‘

This roundâ€™s outcomes were concentrated along two main axes, with a strong emphasis on technical infrastructure:

âœ… Expansion of Cardanoâ€™s technical foundation

A total of 7,568,810 ADA is needed to fund seven community builder projects that have surpassed the 2.69B ADA threshold, which represents 50% + 1 Lovelace of the active registered voting stake.

In GovTool and Ekklesia, I supported six out of the seven projects, but all seven are expected to have a positive impact on the ecosystem.

From Ekklesiaâ€™s voting results, itâ€™s clear that DReps overwhelmingly support these projects, and that should be acknowledged.

Three of the seven projectsâ€”Midgard, Starstream, and ZK Rollupâ€”specifically address scalability, which is the most pressing need for the Cardano ecosystem.

Given this context, voting YES was the only logical choice.

Founding Entity Proposals:

Proposals from founding entities that also met the threshold were intentionally excluded from this governance action. Instead, they are invited to submit their own governance actions for budget requests.

I fully support this decision, as it aligns with the ongoing community debate about the Net Change Limit (NCL).

The current NCL is set at 350M ADA, but a reduction is expected. Two governance actions have been submitted to adjust the NCL to 200M or 300M ADA.

To minimize spending, itâ€™s best to decide on-chain for each proposal individually, rather than bundling multiple proposals into a single governance action.

This approach prevents situations where DReps who support IOGâ€™s budget feel obligated to also back community proposals they disagree with.

Given the circumstances, Intersect has made the right decision, and I appreciate their approach.

meta.title: Cardano Treasury DeFi Liquidity Budget
meta.abstract: The goal of this proposal is to increase liquidity on Cardano, specifically by supporting stablecoin liquidity. 50,000,000 ADA is requested over the course of 12 months (the duration of the budget) to support the Cardano decentralized finance (DeFi) ecosystem. The majority of the funds in this budget will be disbursed to DeFi protocols including decentralized exchanges (DEXs) and lending protocols to help seed liquidity on Cardano. The funds are managed by a 7 person administrating committee composed of publicly identified individuals who are part of multi-signature (multisig) wallet from which liquidity will be managed. This budget is proposed independent of other efforts since the goal of this budget is not to pay developers or companies for ecosystem improvements, rather to increase liquidity in the system overall. Further, unlike other proposals this budget serves as a revenue stream for the Cardano treasury since yields from DeFi protocols will be sent back to the Cardano treasury.
meta.rationale:
### Constitutionality of the Budget

**Purpose**: This proposal is for work intended to enhance the long term sustainability of Cardano by increasing stablecoin liquidity in the ecosystem.

**Article III(5)**: This proposal fulfills this section of the Cardano Constitution by containing a Title, Abstract, Reason for Proposal (Motivation and Rationale), and Supporting Materials. An off-chain copy of this proposal can be found at https://raw.githubusercontent.com/theeldermillenial/2025-liquidity-budget/refs/heads/master/info.jsonld, and the document hash is attached to the transaction to fulfill the other requirements of this section. An easy to read version can be found at https://raw.githubusercontent.com/theeldermillenial/2025-liquidity-budget/refs/heads/master/README.md

**Article IV(1)**: We propose that this budget span 73 epochs (roughly 1 calendar year).

**Article IV(2)**: Disbursements for this budget must be made to a multi-signature (multisig) wallet composed of at least seven independent administrating members with at 4 of 7 signing policy. The process of overseeing funds then requires 4 of the 7 independent administrating members agree to disbursement of funds to DeFi protocols. The wallet must be the owner of any liquidity deposited into DeFi protocols, meaning liquidity tokens or any other assurance of liquidity must be held in the multisig wallet and should not be delegated to a third party, except as required for conversion of assets to fiat or minting of stablecoins. With this design, the committee will be the administrator of the budget funds and will directly oversee distribution of funds to protocols.

**Article IV(3)**: At the time of submission, the NCL is currently at 350 million ADA and there is only one budget requesting 1.5 million ADA that has been submitted on chain through an info action. We believe that this removes a potential constitutional barrier for this proposal based on Article IV(3), since this proposal requests 50 million ADA of the potential remaining 348.5 million ADA.

**Article IV(4)**: We budget 2,000 ADA/month (24,000 ADA total) to cover the costs of audits and transparency. The building of a dashboard and quarterly reporting in the proposed work also fulfill the obligations of this section. Since all funds will be managed from a single account, including all liquidity holdings and disbursement of monthly stipends for administrating committee members, we believe the dashboard and monthly reports are sufficient for auditing. To further strengthen our commitment to the auditing requirement, we also commit to any community driven requests for independent audits via an Info Action, and will use funds up to the $50,000/month budget to work with an independent auditor.

**Article IV(5)**: The nature of the proposed work fulfills the first requirement of Article IV(5) of the constitution. The holding of all assets in the multisig account composed of 7 independent signers improves the ability of the Cardano community to easily audit and track actions taken by the committee. To fulfill the second part of the section, funds will not be delegated to an SPO and will be delegated to the predefined auto-abstain voting option.

**TREASURY-04a**: There is not on chain withdrawal action for this budget, and one will not be submitted unless this budget achieves the necessary 50% approval.
meta.motivation:
### High Level Overview

* **Amount** - The Cardano treasury should dedicate 3.33% of treasury funds (50 million ada) to purchasing fiat backed stablecoins, spread out over 12 monthly purchases. The committee should make every effort to help mitigate the potential price impact of converting ADA to fiat to mint as stable coins over the 12 month period. Note that up to 35% of funds may be held in ADA to pair with ADA/Stablecoin pairs on DEXs, which will help to alleviate price impact concerns.
* **Administration** - A 7 person administrating committee will manage the treasury reserve using a multisig wallet (4 of 7 signature validation) to hold and deploy funds to protocols. The administrating committee will be responsible for working with stablecoin issuers to convert ADA to fiat backed stablecoins and deploying liquidity. A specific focus of the administrating committee will be analyzing approaches of deploying ADA to stablecoins in a way that minimizes ADA price impact.
* **Revenue** - Deployed funds will increase in value according to the interest and fees defined by the protocols fees are disbursed to. Each month the total interest generated by the deployed liquidity will be calculated and 15% of accumulated interest from protocols will be withdrawn from the respective protocols and sent back to the treasury, while the remaining 85% of accumulated interest will remain in the protocol (e.g. analagous but not identical to compounding interest). ADA held by the committee that is not deployed will not be staked according to constitutional requirements (see Rationale for more information).
* **Deployment** - DeFi protocols with at least 250,000 ADA worth of a stablecoin may apply to be recipients of minted stablecoin, and the administrating committee will review and disburse funds to protocols that have the best plans for growth and returns back to the treasury. A maximum of 2 or 3 protocols may be used per DeFi category to help minimize fragmentation. Applicants should make a strong case for the use of their protocol, including a a description of historical success, security, dedicated support for handling issues, and features of the protocol that will maximize the value to the Cardano treasury if liquidity is deployed to the protocol. New protocols will not be excluded for having limited history, but must make a strong case in other areas of the application.
* **Strategy** - The committee will deploy funds on a monthly basis in a way that minimizes ADA price impact and fees. A specific focus should be on deployment of liquidity that can be "passively" managed, meaning frequent adjustements are not needed. The focus on passive management is to help ease the management strategy and reduce the fees incurred by managing liquidity. This may be changed in the future by an on chain Info Action.
* **Audits and Transparency** - The committee is responsible for creating a monthly report or building a dashboard (or both) to describe the ADA held in reserve, the funds deployed to protocols, and all fees and other costs associated with managing the treasury. The committee may use part of the monthly budget to develop a dashboard to provide live updates of the stablecoin reserve for the Cardano community.
* **Costs** - Each member of the committee will be compensated $2,000/month in the fiat backed stablecoin of their choice ($14,000/month total for all committee members). The stablecoin reserve fund will cover the costs of minting fiat backed stables, deployment of liquidity to protocols, and rebalancing if needed. The committe will also use some funds to perform KYB/KYC of 3rd parties as needed as well as cover costs for creation of a legal entity to house the fund. Total costs per month should be capped at $50,000/month over the 12 month period. Any costs that extend beyond the budget period should be deducted from the accrued interest.
* **Organization** - Part of the initial budget will be used to investigate proper incorporation of a legal entity to house the funds being managed for this budget. Every reasonable attempt should be made to house the fund in a non-profit to maximize tax benefits as well as provide future opportunities for organizations to donate to the fund.
* **Revisions** - Since this fund may exist in perpetuity due to funds not being directly spent, it is important to have a mechanism for modification up to and including returning all funds back to the treasury. To this end, any member of the Cardano community may submit an Info Action to modify any aspect of this budget including members of the committee, monthly budget limits, committee pay, and returning some or all of funds back to the treasury. All members of the committee must commit to following any on chain Info Action that is passed by 67% of the community vote. If a committee member does not feel they can continue with their duties at any time, they must continue to carry out their duties until a suitable replacement is found according to the impeachment and replacement mechanisms described below.

### Governing Committee

#### Term Limits

Community members have a maximum term limit of 2 years, after which they can re-apply for a second 2 year term. A minimum of 4 community members (not affiliated with founding entities) must be on the committee at all times.

Founding entities may have at most 1 person each on the committee. There are no term limits for committee members that represent a founding entity, but must still abide by the removal process of an Info Action or a majority vote of the other committee members.

#### Retirement and Impeachment

In the event that a committee member retires or their signing keys are exposed, the remaining members of the committee must create a new multisig address with the same policy (4 of 7) that removes the retired address. This process also gives the committee the capacity to impeach inactive members of the committee, as well as the ability for the community to impeach one or more members through an info action.

#### Community Feedback

The administrating committee members should make themselves available to feedback and questions from the Cardano community, and make attempts to make changes that incorporate reasonable feedback from the community. Feedback can be received through a Telegram channel, on Twitter, scheduled town hall meetings not more than once per month. The administrating committee should make attempts to incorporate feedback from the Cardano community, but are not obligated to do so. If the administrating committee does not respond or refuses to incorporate changes, the Cardano community may submit an on chain Info Action (that achieves 67% approval) to compel the committee to make changes up to and including removal of one or more members and/or returning some or all funds back to the treasury.

#### People

Below are 6 of the 7 members of the initial administrating committee. They range in experience and background to help ensure the long term success and sustainability of the stablecoin liquidity. There is an ongoing search for a 7th member of the committee and will be included in the withdrawal action.
